story:
***PLEASE SCROLL DOWN FOR ENGLISH***

Các bạn thân mến,

Tháng thực hành nghệ thuật 2016 là dự án kéo dài 6 tuần của Heritage Space ra đời với mục đích nuôi dưỡng và phát triển những tài năng nghệ thuật mới của Việt Nam. Dự án tạo ra một không gian nghệ thuật, vốn đang thiếu ở Việt Nam, dành cho các nghệ sĩ trẻ Việt Nam để họ có cơ hội trao đổi, học hỏi với những nghệ sĩ tên tuổi quốc tế, đồng thời mở ra một không gian để công chúng được tiếp cận, tìm hiểu và thưởng thức nghệ thuật đương đại.

Bên cạnh các hoạt động nghệ thuật dành cho công chúng diễn ra xuyên suốt 6 tuần của chương trình, gần 30 nghệ sĩ quốc tế và Việt Nam tham gia vào chương trình, vẫn đang miệt mài sáng tác để cho ra đời những tác phẩm nghệ thuật đặc sắc. Để có thể tiếp tục theo đuổi dự án và mang các tác phẩm nghệ thuật tuyệt vời đó đến với công chúng, chúng tôi rất cần sự quyên góp của tất cả các bạn! Dù là $5, $10 hay $50 cũng đều đáng giá với chúng tôi. Có rất nhiều cách thức để đóng góp:

  • Sử dụng thẻ visa/master tại trang này, bằng cách Nhấn vào BACK IT, điền số tiền bạn mong muốn đóng góp và chọn món quà tương ứng nếu muốn. (Indiegogo là một trang gây quỹ lớn cho phép tất cả những ai quan tâm tới dự án quyên góp tùy theo khả năng của mình và có thể theo dõi tiến trình gây quỹ của dự án một công khai và minh bạch).
  • Chuyển khoản qua tài khoản ngân hàng (thông tin tài khoản tại đây)
  • Tới các sự kiện tại Heritage Space và đóng góp bằng tiền mặt tại các Hòm quyên góp 

Cụ thể, nguồn quỹ mà chúng tôi hiện có chỉ đủ để trả chi phí đi lại, ăn ở và các vật liệu cơ bản cho 12 nghệ sĩ chính thức của chương trình, nhưng chúng tôi đang cố gắng huy động thêm $8,500 sẽ được dùng để:

  • Tổ chức 02 cuộc triển lãm lớn vào cuối dự án để trưng bày cho công chúng các tác phẩm nghệ thuật ra đời trong 6 tuần diễn ra dự án
  • In 500 cuốn sách về dự án trong 2 năm 2015-2016 phục vụ cho mục đích học tập
  • Và hỗ trợ trang thiết bị và vật liệu cho gần 20 nghệ sĩ độc lập tự nguyện đến tham gia và thực hiện các tác phẩm của họ

Mời bạn vào link sau để có thêm thông tin và cập nhật về chiến dịch gây quỹ của chúng tôi, cũng như theo dõi hoạt động của dự án tại Month of Arts practice . Hãy chia sẻ đường link gây quỹ này https://igg.me/at/hsmap với bạn bè và người thân của bạn để chúng ta cùng nhau tạo ra một sân chơi nghệ thuật đúng nghĩa cho nghệ sĩ và công chúng Việt Nam!

Xin chân thành cám ơn sự ủng hộ của các bạn!

Mời bạn xem thêm thông tin bằng tiếng Anh bên dưới.

WHAT IS MONTH OF ARTS PRACTICE?

‘Month of Arts Practice’ (HSMAP) is an ambitious art project of Heritage Space, an independent art space in Hanoi (Vietnam).

HSMAP was initiated in 2015 in response to a great lack of educational and development opportunity for young artists in Vietnam. Every year, there will be established artists from overseas who are invited to come and work with Hanoi-based young, emerging, talented artists in a period of 4-6 weeks at Heritage Space. Apart from artwork creation by artists, a wide range of activities are organized such as workshops and presentations by artists, curators or specialists, film screening, musical performance and discussion, art visits or impromptu showcases. All activities are open to public, and the audience is encouraged to join and interact with artists, or being part of the art creation process. At the end of the project, all artworks are displayed for public’s appreciation.

Artist in residence Isaac Cordal photographing his sculptures in Hanoi.

Following the success of HSMAP 2015, this year's HSMAP came back with 5 established artists from Europe and America and 7 young emerging artists from Hanoi. Art dialogues and activities for the public have been heating up the art atmosphere in Hanoi more than ever. (For more information and updates, click here). There are in addition nearly 20 independent artists who volunteered to join in to exchange and create art, which reconfirms the desire to learn and communicate of artists in Hanoi.

Last year's exhibition 'Brownian Movement', the Grand show of 'Month of Arts Practice' 2015 .

HSMAP 2016 artists exchanging ideas.

WHY IS HSMAP SO IMPORTANT TO US?

The aim of the HSMAP project is twofold: we want to nurture and develop young Vietnamese talents through interaction with and learning from well-known international artists and enhance the art comprehension and appreciation amongst local residents.

In Vietnam, until now, there has been no source of support for contemporary arts from the Government or Enterprises. Contemporary art, be it theory or practice, is not taught at schools, and young artists face a lot of hardship in studying contemporary art by themselves. Many young talents were missed out because of the poor working conditions, as well as capacity and skills constraints. Art spaces are also extremely limited for artists to work and exhibit.

The public in Hanoi also does not have many chances to enjoy contemporary art because of a limited number of art space dedicated to contemporary art. Through interactive workshops, open dialogues and exhibitions, we hope to bring art closer to the residents of Hanoi and over the long run, create and strengthen a local art community.

Art Talk by Kasia Klon, participating artist of 'Month of Arts Practice'  2016.

Workshop with artist George Burchett.

HOW YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE?

Thanks to the generosity of our main sponsor, we have enough funding to cover travel expenses, accommodation and art materials for the 12 featured artists. But in order to bring the amazing artworks realized during the project to the public, we need your help. Be part of it and help us create more chances for artists and create great art for Hanoi!

We aim to raise another $8,500 which will allow us to:

  • Organize 02 important exhibitions at Heritage Space Gallery and Royal City Square in downtown Hanoi which cost $2,000
  • Publicate 500 books and brochures about the project for the period of 2015-2016 with works of more than 40 artists, which cost $4000
  • And support the materials for nearly 20 independent artists who volunteered to come exchange, work and create art for the exhibitions, which cost $2,500

We would appreciate each $5, $10, $50 from you because many smalls make a great. We believe with each of your support, even the slightest, will help us get there.

PERKS  

This project wouldn't be possible without your support. Check out our awesome list of perks we've come up with as a way to say thank you for your help. If you can't contribute money, please take a moment to share the campaign with your friends and family as every bit helps!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

WHO'S BEHIND 'MONTH OF ARTS PRACTICE'?

Heritage Space is a non-profit arts organization supporting the development of local contemporary art, as well as creating meeting and cooperation opportunities of various creative fields.

Foundations & organizations supporting culture and art in Vietnam are extremely rare, and there is almost no support for contemporary art. Local artists, therefore, have very little opportunity to discuss and work in professional environment, learn and discuss with specialists, creating their own network, thus encounter numerous difficulties for their long-term art career. Heritage Space was thus born to bridge this gap.

On the other hand, community activities such as talk, exhibition, workshops organized regularly at Heritage Space will help bring contemporary art closer to the public, raise interests, and in the future will be a source of long term patronage for art and artists.

Who are the ARTISTS?

  • Alia Ali (New Orleans, United States)
  • Isaac Cordal (Brussels, Belgium)
  • Natalie Contenay (Paris, France)
  • Marija Lopac (Zagreb, Croatia)
  • Santiago Reyes (Ecuador & Paris, France)
  • Quách Bắc (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Thùy Diên (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Kim Duy (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Lê Giang (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Triệu Tuấn Long (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Chu Quỳnh (Hanoi, Vietnam)
  • Trịnh Nhật Vũ (Hanoi, Vietnam)

 

Please scroll down for artist biography!

And say hello to our dedicated volunteer team!
  •     Project Manager, Curator - Nguyen Anh Tuan (Heritage Space, Hanoi, Vietnam)
  •     Assistant Manager, Art researcher - Vu Huy Thong (Institute of Arts, Hanoi, Vietnam)
  •     Founder - Artist Tran Trong Vu (Paris, France)

-----

MORE about ARTIST, CURATOR and ORGANIZER:

Curator & Organizer

Tran Trong Vu
(Paris, France & Hanoi, Vietnam)
Tran Trong Vu attended the Hanoi University of Fine Arts from 1982 to 1987, where he developed a reputable portfolio, winning many awards.  In 1987 he was awarded a scholarship to continue his studies at the Rcole Nationale des Beaux-Arts in Paris.  Vu employs a social realist style in depicting the social conformity and bureucracy of his homeland. Vu has exhibited throughout the U.S., Asia, and Europe.  His major showings include solo exhibitions in Vietnam, France, and at UCLA and Arizona State University.

Nguyen Anh Tuan
(Hanoi, Vietnam)
Nguyen Anh Tuan is a independent curator and artistic manager based in Hanoi. His works includes important art exhibitions and project in Vietnam in recent years, such as New Form - a project of Researching and Experimenting new concepts in sculpture from 2013 - 2014, art project Initiative Contemporary Arts Museum in Vietnam (2013, Muong Studio, curated by Tran Luong), ECOart - a project of Researching and Experimenting in ecological arts (Muong Studio, 2015), and international art exhibition Yu Yu Vietnam Blue (Vietnam Fine Arts Museum, 2015). At this moment he is Artistic Director of Heritage Space art center in Hanoi, Manager of Muong AIR - the Artist-in-Residency program of Muong Studio for both local and international artists. In beginning of 2016, Indochina Arts Partnerships (IAP) - an non-profit organization working in art exchange between Vietnam - United Stated, invites Tuan to be a Country director in Vietnam.

Vu Huy Thong
(Hanoi, Vietnam)
Vu Huy Thong is a art researcher based in Hanoi, Vietnam. His works focus on Vietnamese contemporary arts activities, frequently being published at academic journals like Fine Arts Research journal (Institute of Arts, Vietnam Fine Arts University), Arts & Culture journal (Vietnam Ministry of Culture) and Fine Arts & Photography (Bureau of Fine Arts, Photography and Exhibition). He also involves into translating job for many important art exchanges like workshops, exhibitions, educating businesses between Germany and Vietnam by collaborations between DAAD, Goethe Institute (Hanoi) with Vietnam Fine Arts Museum and Vietnam Fine Art University.

-----

Artists

1. Alia Ali (Austria, 1985) is a Yemeni-Bosnian-American multi-media artist and visual storyteller. Having traveled to ﬁfty-three countries, lives in seven and grown up among ﬁve languages, her most comfortable mode of communication is through image and multi-sensory mediums. Alia's aesthetic interests stem from people, place, and the processes which unite and divide us, all at once.

2. Santiago Reyes - has mainly worked in Paris, but he has taken part in numerous exhibitions and art events in Europe, the Americas and Asia. His work deals with body-centered poetics, the appropriation of public and institutional spaces and relational art practices. His renewed approach to performance deserves special mention, however, since it is a means of expression to which he often resorts, and that runs through much of his work. His main interests include questioning the relationships between the individual and culture, the porous borders that separate the public from the private, the fleeting nature of human relationships, the mutability of our sense of origin and belonging, and an acute awareness of temporality, mobility and displacement. 

3. Nathalie Contenay (1965) is a French visual artist. She participated in various group exhibitions and residencies in Europe and the U.S, as well as owns more than 20 solo exhibitions held in France, Germany and Italy, among which the important exhibition Ombres et Lumières at the Centre Georges Pompidou (2005, Paris) and her latest exhibition is Irradiances (2016, Paris).

4. Isaac Cordal, born in 1974 in Pontevedra, Spain, Cordal graduated from the University of Fine Arts Pontevedra. He also trained at Camberwell College of Arts in London and studied for five years at the School of Canteiros Pontevedra, a school dedicated to the conservation of stone crafts. He was the founding member of Alg-a.org, digital art community from Galicia, and the part of the artistic collective Ludd34560 and Sr. Pause. For the past 10 years, Cordal has been devoted to his practice as his cement sculptures have been seen in many cities worldwide.

5. Marija Lopac (1983) is a Croatian visual artist. He participated in many exhibitions around the world, including Vietnam (Hue, 2014). She is always interested in what is happening inside the thoughts, memories, ideas, joy, and imagination and projecting them onto a large three dimensional space. She worked as a lecturer in art in her country, then decided to leave and travel all over the world.

6. Le Giang (1988) is an artist living and working in Hanoi. She received her bachelor's degree in Art Education from Vietnam University of Fine Art and a master's degree in Fine Art from Camberwell College of Arts, University of the Arts London. Le Giang was part of many group exhibitions in London, joined other group exhibitions both in Vietnam and other countries, such as Spot Art Young South East Asia Art Festival (Singapore), Above Under Sky (Manzi art space), Into thin air (Public space at 61 Ly Thai To, Hanoi, Vietnam). In 2013 and 2015, Le Giang participated to two art residencies in Japan (Haisyakkei Artist in Residency) and Philippines (98B COLLABoratory Artist Research and Project Residency through San Art), at the same time had her solo exhibitions namely “Reincarnate” and “Nostalgia from Nature” in these countries.

7. Trinh Nhat Vu (1990) graduated from Vietnam University of Fine Art. Trinh Nhat Vu has participated in many exhibitions, from local ones such as Young Artist Club Exhibition (16 Ngo Quyen Exhibition House), Group Exhibition “E.A.T” (Viet Art Centre), Group Exhibition “A4 Garden” (Vietnam University of Fine Arts), to other international projects, namely More than a Monarch, The 11th International Art Workshop (Thailand), Pulau Ketam International Arts Festival 2014 (Malaysia), The Silk Road International Arts Festival (China), The 15th International Calligraphy and Painting Exchange Exhibition (Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum).

8. Nguyen Kim Duy (1987) is an artist currently living and working in Hanoi, Vietnam. He graduated from Academy of Fine Art Nuremberg (2014) and Faculty of Painting at Vietnam University of Fine Arts (2008).

Coming back Vietnam since July 2014, Kim Duy starts practice and introduce his Conceptual arts by various media and appearance via series of exhibitions in Heritage Space, Nha San Collective (2014, 2015), Group Exhibition Yu Yu Vietnam Blue (Vietnam Museum of Fine Arts, 2015), Open Room II (2016, CAPA Studio, Hochiminh city).

9. Chu Thi Thuy Quynh (1991) is an artist living and working in Hanoi, Vietnam.She participated in the group exhibition of Art Diversity III at Work Room Four (2014) with Zincography, “Yu Yu Vietnam Blue” exhibition at Vietnam Fine Arts Museum (2015) with Installation using a variety of materials.

10. Thuy Dien (1992) is a female young artist living and working in Hanoi. Although she studied in National Economics University, she has the innate artistic and have passion and creativity of making doll and small house when she was 14 years old. She participated in Month of Arts Pratice 2015 with the theme “The Brownian Movement”. Her art form are photography and installation made from small dolls and furniture in order to create the sense of a really special personal world, evoque the daydreaming and also the loneliness and the embarrassment in search of an identity, such as the story about the existential identity crisis of modern time.

11. Quach Bac (1988) graduated in Painting, Fine Arts University Vietnam. His artworks express the psychological depth by a solid painting technique and multimedia. Quach Bac won the award Independent Young Talent in 2016 and had the residency creation in Malaysia, as well as participated in numerous exhibitions in Vietnam. In 2015, Quach Bach also attended in Month at Heritage Space with the theme “Brownian Movement “.

12. Trieu Tuan Long (1981) graduated in Art Education, Fine Arts University Vietnam. As an artist with strong and also romantic instincts, Trieu Tuan Long's painting is full of passionate feeling in life under a romantic sense of artist. He had arranged the personal exhibition entitled "Transmission of information by horsepower " at L' Espace 2014, besides the regular participation of group exhibitions, the Young Artist Club, Fine Arts Exhibition of Vietnam Fine Arts Association.

Thank you!​

http://heritagespace.com/
story_txt:
***PLEASE SCROLL DOWN FOR ENGLISH***Các bạn thân mến,Tháng thực hành nghệ thuật 2016 là dự án kéo dài 6 tuần của Heritage Space ra đời với mục đích nuôi dưỡng và phát triển những tài năng nghệ thuật mới của Việt Nam. Dự án tạo ra một không gian nghệ thuật, vốn đang thiếu ở Việt Nam, dành cho các nghệ sĩ trẻ Việt Nam để họ có cơ hội trao đổi, học hỏi với những nghệ sĩ tên tuổi quốc tế, đồng thời mở ra một không gian để công chúng được tiếp cận, tìm hiểu và thưởng thức nghệ thuật đương đại.Bên cạnh các hoạt động nghệ thuật dành cho công chúng diễn ra xuyên suốt 6 tuần của chương trình, gần 30 nghệ sĩ quốc tế và Việt Nam tham gia vào chương trình, vẫn đang miệt mài sáng tác để cho ra đời những tác phẩm nghệ thuật đặc sắc. Để có thể tiếp tục theo đuổi dự án và mang các tác phẩm nghệ thuật tuyệt vời đó đến với công chúng, chúng tôi rất cần sự quyên góp của tất cả các bạn! Dù là $5, $10 hay $50 cũng đều đáng giá với chúng tôi. Có rất nhiều cách thức để đóng góp:

Sử dụng thẻ visa/master tại trang này, bằng cách Nhấn vào BACK IT, điền số tiền bạn mong muốn đóng góp và chọn món quà tương ứng nếu muốn. (Indiegogo là một trang gây quỹ lớn cho phép tất cả những ai quan tâm tới dự án quyên góp tùy theo khả năng của mình và có thể theo dõi tiến trình gây quỹ của dự án một công khai và minh bạch).

Chuyển khoản qua tài khoản ngân hàng (thông tin tài khoản tại đây)
Tới các sự kiện tại Heritage Space và đóng góp bằng tiền mặt tại các Hòm quyên góp 
Cụ thể, nguồn quỹ mà chúng tôi hiện có chỉ đủ để trả chi phí đi lại, ăn ở và các vật liệu cơ bản cho 12 nghệ sĩ chính thức của chương trình, nhưng chúng tôi đang cố gắng huy động thêm $8,500 sẽ được dùng để:
Tổ chức 02 cuộc triển lãm lớn vào cuối dự án để trưng bày cho công chúng các tác phẩm nghệ thuật ra đời trong 6 tuần diễn ra dự án
In 500 cuốn sách về dự án trong 2 năm 2015-2016 phục vụ cho mục đích học tập
Và hỗ trợ trang thiết bị và vật liệu cho gần 20 nghệ sĩ độc lập tự nguyện đến tham gia và thực hiện các tác phẩm của họ
Mời bạn vào link sau để có thêm thông tin và cập nhật về chiến dịch gây quỹ của chúng tôi, cũng như theo dõi hoạt động của dự án tại Month of Arts practice . Hãy chia sẻ đường link gây quỹ này https://igg.me/at/hsmap với bạn bè và người thân của bạn để chúng ta cùng nhau tạo ra một sân chơi nghệ thuật đúng nghĩa cho nghệ sĩ và công chúng Việt Nam!Xin chân thành cám ơn sự ủng hộ của các bạn!Mời bạn xem thêm thông tin bằng tiếng Anh bên dưới. WHAT IS MONTH OF ARTS PRACTICE?‘Month of Arts Practice’ (HSMAP) is an ambitious art project of Heritage Space, an independent art space in Hanoi (Vietnam).HSMAP was initiated in 2015 in response to a great lack of educational and development opportunity for young artists in Vietnam. Every year, there will be established artists from overseas who are invited to come and work with Hanoi-based young, emerging, talented artists in a period of 4-6 weeks at Heritage Space. Apart from artwork creation by artists, a wide range of activities are organized such as workshops and presentations by artists, curators or specialists, film screening, musical performance and discussion, art visits or impromptu showcases. All activities are open to public, and the audience is encouraged to join and interact with artists, or being part of the art creation process. At the end of the project, all artworks are displayed for public’s appreciation.Artist in residence Isaac Cordal photographing his sculptures in Hanoi.Following the success of HSMAP 2015, this year's HSMAP came back with 5 established artists from Europe and America and 7 young emerging artists from Hanoi. Art dialogues and activities for the public have been heating up the art atmosphere in Hanoi more than ever. (For more information and updates, click here). There are in addition nearly 20 independent artists who volunteered to join in to exchange and create art, which reconfirms the desire to learn and communicate of artists in Hanoi.Last year's exhibition 'Brownian Movement', the Grand show of 'Month of Arts Practice' 2015 .HSMAP 2016 artists exchanging ideas.WHY IS HSMAP SO IMPORTANT TO US?The aim of the HSMAP project is twofold: we want to nurture and develop young Vietnamese talents through interaction with and learning from well-known international artists and enhance the art comprehension and appreciation amongst local residents.In Vietnam, until now, there has been no source of support for contemporary arts from the Government or Enterprises. Contemporary art, be it theory or practice, is not taught at schools, and young artists face a lot of hardship in studying contemporary art by themselves. Many young talents were missed out because of the poor working conditions, as well as capacity and skills constraints. Art spaces are also extremely limited for artists to work and exhibit.The public in Hanoi also does not have many chances to enjoy contemporary art because of a limited number of art space dedicated to contemporary art. Through interactive workshops, open dialogues and exhibitions, we hope to bring art closer to the residents of Hanoi and over the long run, create and strengthen a local art community.Art Talk by Kasia Klon, participating artist of 'Month of Arts Practice'  2016.Workshop with artist George Burchett.HOW YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE?Thanks to the generosity of our main sponsor, we have enough funding to cover travel expenses, accommodation and art materials for the 12 featured artists. But in order to bring the amazing artworks realized during the project to the public, we need your help. Be part of it and help us create more chances for artists and create great art for Hanoi!We aim to raise another $8,500 which will allow us to:
Organize 02 important exhibitions at Heritage Space Gallery and Royal City Square in downtown Hanoi which cost $2,000
Publicate 500 books and brochures about the project for the period of 2015-2016 with works of more than 40 artists, which cost $4000
And support the materials for nearly 20 independent artists who volunteered to come exchange, work and create art for the exhibitions, which cost $2,500
We would appreciate each $5, $10, $50 from you because many smalls make a great. We believe with each of your support, even the slightest, will help us get there.


PERKS  


This project wouldn't be possible without your support. Check out our awesome list of perks we've come up with as a way to say thank you for your help. If you can't contribute money, please take a moment to share the campaign with your friends and family as every bit helps!

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 
WHO'S BEHIND 'MONTH OF ARTS PRACTICE'?
Heritage Space is a non-profit arts organization supporting the development of local contemporary art, as well as creating meeting and cooperation opportunities of various creative fields.
Foundations & organizations supporting culture and art in Vietnam are extremely rare, and there is almost no support for contemporary art. Local artists, therefore, have very little opportunity to discuss and work in professional environment, learn and discuss with specialists, creating their own network, thus encounter numerous difficulties for their long-term art career. Heritage Space was thus born to bridge this gap.
On the other hand, community activities such as talk, exhibition, workshops organized regularly at Heritage Space will help bring contemporary art closer to the public, raise interests, and in the future will be a source of long term patronage for art and artists.

story:
WHO ARE WE?

We are a group of South Minneapolis builders, welders, engineers, artists, neighbors and creators who collaborate on a volunteer basis to create a submission to the Mayday Parade. These projects come from our passion to create interactive art spectacles for and by the community. 

May 1, 2016 is the day! This is our 8th year of participation in the Heart of the Beast's May Day Parade and celebration. People from all over the Twin Cities and beyond gather every year to celebrate the coming of spring with The Heart of the Beast's parade and festival in Powderhorn Park, now in its 42st year. (http://hobt.org/mayday/parade/)

THIS YEAR…

We build on last year's Southside Schooner to create the boat frame and bowsprit! We will also renovate the Grill Trailer, repair the Shanty and Ferris Wheel, improve our fire show and fix the air-powered train horn. While we are working, who knows what we will invent to add on!

WHY DONATE?

This campaign is to raise funds for materials and build space ONLY. All of our participation is passion based; we do not get paid for our involvement. 

The money you donate will be used to purchase: steel, fix trailers, propane, electricity and welding consumables and quality food that will be cooked and passed our for free the day of the parade. You make this possible! Look at the photos.

WORKSHOPS! Come by and check us out, get to know us.
Bring ideas, skills, questions, food, time, hands, excitement. Workshop days will be announced in April and will be at 3100 Portland Ave S. in the GARAGE.

Spread the word! 
Let people know about us. We can use all the support financially and hands at the workshops. 

Check us out on Facebook and share this Indiegogo fundraiser page. Stay tuned for workshops, which will be open to the public.

story:
Hello everyone !

We kindly invite you to participate in the international light festival“Beepositive 2016" on October the 1st in Vilnius, Lithuania!

The international light festival “Beepositive” is a lighting design and installation festival, held every year since 2011 in autumn,on the first weekend of October in Vilnius, Lithuania. It is a one of a kind cultural festival, which attracts more than 11 000 people per day. The festival has its own unique creative workshops, educational and cultural programs, craft markets and other attractions suitable for everyone – children and adults. Over 50 light installations and around 20 other activities are opened for guests. Every “Beepositive” visitor becomes not just a guest, but also a participant.

The FREE festival is being organized for the 6th time by a non-government organization, a culture center and creative workshop called“Beepart”, located in Vilnius, Lithuania. “Beepart” stands for ecology, culture, creativity and most important – community. “Beepart” was established in 2009 and the initiator of the idea is Andrius Ciplijauskas. The culture center is situated inside an eco-friendly building, made from sea containers and uses only electricity to power it up. “Beepart” organizes many cultural events, various activities, which involve not only the district of Pilaitė (where the culture center is situated), but the whole city of Vilnius. The light installation festival “Beepositive” is the organizations biggest project which it is best known for.

This year is extremely tough with the financial support - we received only 1/3 of the funds we usually get from our cities municipality and now rely only on donations from people. Each year we had live performances by various musicians and bands, but its seems that we will not be able to afford to make a stage this year. The festival takes place both near and in the forest, so making a good stage isn't easy. We need about 3000 USD to build a decent stage near the forest, transport every piece and rent high quality speakers, install them on trees. We also plan to spend the left-over money (if there will be some) on gifts and souvenirs for artists that will perform on the stage and also for more unique installations.  

During the organization of the festival, we cooperate with various Lithuanian and foreign artists, students, volunteers, creative and active people. But the most important group are you – the contributors and visitors of the festival! Only you can make this happen, so we are kindly inviting you to come and be a part of this unique experience.The festival is completely free and everyone is welcome. Maybe this could be your chance to visit the Baltic region and our beautiful country Lithuania with its historic capital city Vilnius and  also participate in the festival.

We are a non-profit seeking organization which is funded by private initiative and your support is very important to us. We would be thankful for your personal donation to help make this festival a reality and delight people once again. 

For more information about the festival, pictures and videos, please visit the official website for the festival http://www.beepositive.lt/en/home/. If you have questions, ideas or proposals or would like to participate in the festival, please contact us at info@beepart.lt.

With our brightest regards,

The team of “Beepart”.

story:
DANDELION COLLECTIVE

A Place for Expression. A Place for Inclusion

The Dandelion Collective is an inclusive platform passionate about dance. We work with performers of all ages and backgrounds and are interested in the individual rather than the technical perfection of dance. Because of this we create particularly fascinating work, that has gained great recognition both across the professional and community dance sector. For the past three years, Dandelion Collective have worked in a variety of communities, we hold weekly dance sessions and engage in regular public performances across London.





Our upcoming Performance Event

'Making Respect for the Dignity of Life the Spirit of the Age'

will celebrate the human spirit and provide a platform where adults with or without  a learning difficulty and/or physical disability perform alongside professional and non-professional dancers. The event will take place at the New Diorama Theatre in London this May.

We strongly believe in the impact this event will have on both our performers and the attending audience. We seek to use this event to deepen and expand our understanding of the work of Dandelion Collective.

By helping us realize this event, you become part of an important milestone in the development of the Dandelion Collective and create a powerful cause towards a truly equal performance platform. 

Our performances are always filled with sincerity, laughter and inspiration. Even if you claim to be one of these people who doesn't dance, you may catch yourself burst into random moves the next morning.

What will we use your financial support for?

Your donations will enable us to:

  • pay the collaborating artists
  • pay for rehearsal space 
  • cover general expenses of the event, ie. advertising, props, costumes etc.


We are committed to:

  • Providing high-level artistic work

  • Inspiring the community through this event

  • Empowering the individual through the theme of the event

  • Employing local, London based artists


We will be grateful if you can share this campaign with anyone you think may be interested in supporting this event or finding out about us.

Thank you so much for your support!!

Esther Huss + Cristina Garcia

Founders of Dandelion Collective

www.dandelion-collective.org

Dandelion Facebook

story:
Summary

Hello world! My name is Jillian, I am a dedicated art teacher and I am trying to raise the funds to build a studio for my amazing students at Pan African Academy and High School. Over the past two years, I have been developing and teaching an art program at a mission school in Kenya (Pan African). It began as an interesting opportunity I took in between my undergrad and teacher's college but it has grown into a project that has changed the course of my life. I have grown attached to these wonderful students who wasted no time at all in proving their talent, enthusiasm and commitment to me. 

My fundraising goal is the estimated cost to have the studio built including both materials and labour. I am hoping that there will also be enough funds to furnish the room with some tables, stools and easels but we will cross that bridge when we get to it. Any extra funds raised will go into the account we have set up for the art program and will be used in the future to buy art supplies, tools and/or equipment. 

A Little History

I guess I should begin with how I got involved with Pan African Schools in the first place. It all began when I went to Kenya for a couple of weeks with a small group from the church I was attending at the time. While I was there, I met the director of PACE (Pan African Christian Exchange) Ministries. When he found out that I was going through for French and Art he says with a meaningful look, “Art? I don’t have an Art teacher” and in case I didn’t get the hint, he immediately follows up with “No wait, yes I do and she’s sitting right in front of me”. I didn’t know it at the time, but that moment was about to change the course of my life. 

I mulled it over for a while and eventually decided to go teach art at PACE for a term between my undergrad and teacher’s college. I figured it would be an excellent experience, but I didn’t realize that it would change my life forever. I travelled back to Kenya in April 2014 and taught from May to August at Pan African Academy and Pan African High School. But you see, I did not anticipate how wonderful and talented the students would be, nor how much they would love and value the program. Before I knew it, I was convinced that I had to come back the following year and continue the program. So, when I finished teacher’s college in 2015, I returned and taught again for the same school term. As I watched my students grow and develop it became clear to me that I had started something much bigger than I had anticipated. Now, here I am, committed to continuing the program and trying to raise the funds to build a studio for these children who have stolen my heart. 

Why It’s Important

I could think of a million reasons why this program means so much to me but I will share just a few here:

1) Art is a real career option for some of these students if they are given the instruction and resources to develop their talent. This has already been proven to me as I watched 4 of my more advanced students successfully sell their work last year.

2) It builds confidence and gives students a voice. As we all know, not every student is academically gifted but most who are not have other talents. Art happens to be one of those talents. I have seen students enter my art room and become completely different people. I have watched a child’s self esteem flourish because they have finally found something they are good at. And even those who are not particularly gifted still find joy and a sense of accomplishment when they create something of their own. 

3) It’s something that they can control. I recall one of my students telling me that he liked painting because no matter what’s going on around him, no matter how bad things might be sometimes, when he paints, he can make something beautiful, he can make it come out however he likes. This statement broke my heart and it showed me how valuable this program has become for some of these kids. As you might imagine, not all of my students have easy lives outside of school. There are a lot of things in their lives that they simply have no power over but their art is something that they can control. It’s something that gives them the power to hope, to dream and to imagine things as they might be rather than just as they are.

Why Do We Need a Studio?

Though we have been making do with whatever little room is available to us thus far, I am of the opinion that these children deserve a real studio for several reasons:

1) We need a bigger space. The room that we have been using is only large enough for about 15 students at a time and last year I had about 60 art students in total. Though I never had all of them at once, my room was still over capacity on a daily basis. I would like to have a larger space so that more students are able to work at the same time.

2) We need a sink. So far I have been sending students to the communal tap to collect water for washing brushes and such. However, I would like to teach them screen printing in the future and I simply cannot send them to the communal tap to wash out printing screens. Every art room should have a sink and this will be included in our studio.

3) We need storage space. With so many talented students, the masterpieces start to pile up on top of each other. I had to start plastering the walls with work just for a place to put it all. Also, because many of the students are boarders, their work cannot be sent home with them until the end of the school term which results in a pretty big pile-up. 

4) A studio will provide a space of their own where students may work year-round. Unfortunately, I cannot afford to stay the whole year as my position is strictly volunteer. This however, means that when I go back to Canada, the space we were using does not always remain available to my students. If they had a studio though, it would be their space and it would be available to them during the rest of the school year as well.

How You Can Help

Donations of any amount are all helpful and greatly appreciated. It will take a lot of help from a lot of people to make this dream a reality but I believe that with your help, we can get there!

How You Can Help Donations of any amount are all helpful and greatly appreciated. It will take a lot of help from a lot of people to make this dream a reality but I believe that with your help, we can get there!

story:
The Arctic is a part of the world undergoing dramatic changes that effect us all. It is an isolated, beautiful, vulnerable ecosystem with a habitat that has an important role to play in maintaining the balance in ecosystems closer to home. 

It's therefore critical that we understand how our consumption of resources impacts on environments such as this, and how we relate to our environment through our dependence on it. Indigenous crafts that are used to record resources and navigate provide an opportunity to visualise and comprehend how the interaction between land, resources and human ingenuity changes over time.


This campaign exists to raise funds for a unique, once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to enable me to take part in an artist-in-residency program aboard a research vessel in the Arctic Circle (The Arctic Circle Residency). I have been invited, along with a small group of international artists and scientists, to participate in the residency in the remote northern archipelago of Svalbard, both on land and on the arctic seas. The project I will be carrying out in the Arctic is called Making in Transit and is an exploration of how indigenous crafts are used to understand our environment.


The Impact

Making in Transit aims to recreate indigenous crafts used for numerical recording and navigation within the Arctic Circle. These crafts will be used to record geological structures and monitor expedition resource consumption, specifically by means of; the ancient Incan Quipu and Inuit hand-carved tactile maps (such as the Ammasalik maps of Greenland). 



These crafts have been chosen because or their ability to navigate space, record data, communicate, and help humans plan and organise their lives. These incredible examples of human ingenuity demonstrate how craft relates to resources and thus explores the relationship between our environment and 'making'. 

In a world dominated by screen-based technology, the ability of the Quipu and Inuit maps to serve as tactile data representation makes their appeal to use as educational tools in interactive workshops both engaging and powerful. I intend to explore the role of handmade technology and (re)discover the relationships that can be formed with our environment through making.

As well as enabling me to take part in this residency, raising funds through this campaign will enable me to share my experience though an exhibition and school workshops that explore subjects such as geography, design and statistics.

A large part of the Making in Transit timeline occurs after I return from the Arctic Circle Residency, in the form of a series of workshops run in London schools (at the The Ellen Wilkinson School for Girls, Harris Academies and Notting Hill School).  Conversations are also underway regarding workshops with schools in Cardiff, Glasgow, Denmark, Sweden and Norway on my return journey to London from Svalbard in order to engage more school students in the project. Making in Transit will also culminate in a public exhibition in Central London, which will be open to the public free of charge. 

All Making in Transit learning resources created for the workshops will be made available for school teachers to use and adapt free of charge on  TES.com (a learning resource archive used by teachers). The Making in Transit resources will be of use for teachers of geography, physics, mathematics, art and design, technology and engineering, and will be adapted to be suitable for Key Stages 1–5. 

Please note: I am taking my own time out of employment to carry out this work and will not receive any personal financial gain. I am totally reliant on donors and other potential sources of funding to complete this work. 



Who am I?

My name is Jennifer Crouch, I am a school teacher, artist, lecturer and co-founder of the Art-Physics project Jiggling Atoms. I also work as current artist in residence at the UCL Centre for Advanced Biomedical Imaging (CABI) carrying out a long-term project about the relationship between craftsmanship and scientific research.  

In addition to having exhibited artwork prolifically and internationally, I have also lectured at Central Saint Martins (where I am tutor on the course in Anatomical Drawing), Imperial College, Camberwell College of Arts, Bournemouth and Northampton University. I have a proven track record of running workshops, teaching school students and graduates, and organising successful exhibitions and public engagement events with organisations such as Jiggling Atoms.  I also teach design and technology in a secondary school and make artwork that explores science and technology through craft, ceramics, workshops and pictorial representation. I studied physics followed by Illustration at university and later trained as a medical illustrator. Currently I am training to become a teacher with the School Direct training scheme and completing my PGCE at Goldsmiths University – as learning underpins my artistic work, it felt right to learn how to teach! 



What I Need & What You Get

I will only be able to take part in the Arctic Circle Residency if I can raise enough money to make it there and cover participation costs. I need to raise a total of £6,000. 

Travelling through the Arctic Circle, putting on an exhibition and delivering educational workshops to schools are complicated affairs and reaching my target will enable me to do all these things, covering:

  • Expedition participation on board the ship from our point of departure to the return point in Longyearbyen (30th September and 19th October 2016).
  • Excursions on land in order to carry out essential practical work for the project.
  • Return train travel between London, Cardiff, Glasgow, Denmark, Sweden and Norway, and a return flight to Svalbard to enable visiting of destinations along the way for public engagement workshops in schools. 
  • All materials for workshops for use in the UK and abroad (simple portable carving tools, wood for carving and clay).
  • Exhibition costs and to cover talks at the exhibition given by expert guest speakers, who will discuss issues such as climate change, anthropology, the arctic ecosystem.

All donations will contribute towards the expedition, whether I exceed or fall short of my target. During the educational workshops students will be taught about the Quipu and tactile carved maps and have a chance to create their own (from soft materials such as soap bars or clay.) Their maps and Quipu will be used to explore their own local environment and record resource use around them. Beginning to engage with and compare our potential impact on our environment is the first step towards understanding how to respond to change. The more money I raise, the more people I can share this project with. 



So far, generous supporters of Making in Transit include The Cube project space in East London, who have kindly offered the use of their exhibition space to host the Making in Transit exhibition from December 2016 to February 2017, free of charge! This will enable visitors to see the work I will create in the Arctic, meet experts and researchers, ask questions and express concerns about important issues surrounding climate change. Below is an image of the entrance of The Cube. I'm really excited about what this project could achieve, not only experiencing the vast, cold Arctic and producing work there, but knowing that there is a platform where this can be shared following this.  


Perks for donors

Various ‘perks’ are available to donors, providing supporters with opportunities to own some of my artwork, in addition to owning hand-carved maps, Quipu and other artefacts created during the Arctic Circle residency. All contributions of financial assistance are gratefully received, with all donors receiving regular updates on the project via the project website as well as invites to the final exhibition.  

As well as creating limited edition prints, ornamental printed ceramic tiles and commemorative plates especially for this campaign, other prints from 

the Magic Calendar series and printed textiles are also available for donors to this campaign.  



Above is a close-up of the Making in Transit riso print inspired by the Arctic landscape and geology which you can also select as a perk.

Printed anatomical plates, as well as paintings and hand-painted ceramic pieces that were hired for use on the set of the  Paddington Bear film, are also up for grabs (if you have seen the film, these paintings, drawings and plates are in the background of the kitchen and bathroom scenes). 


Below are the Making in Transit commemorative ceramic tiles that you can also select as a perk! Six different designs available! 


One particular work of art I have made available includes a piece called the ‘infinite landscape’ that was created for my second solo exhibition in 2009, it consists of 9 different images that can be rearranged and connected into 362,880 different combinations.  I am making a large range of my works available as perks to encourage as many people to donate as possible, so this is a good chance to own some of my work.

The above painting is available and is called Flatland: be patient for the world is broad and wide. This painting was exhibited in the prestigious 2012 Threadneedle Prize exhibition. Select the perk called Flatland for this one. Other paintings are also available as perks!


Risks and Challenges

Working full-time as a teacher in a secondary school in London is a difficult but rewarding job; balancing this with my creative endeavours and professional artistic practice is indeed a challenge, but one I am dedicated to. I am passionate about bringing together art projects and education, and residency schemes like this enable me to do this, uniting keys interests of mine such as data representation, indigenous crafts and environmental issues, all of which have an important ethical dimension in today’s world. It was indeed a challenge getting a place on the residency, but now the next challenge is funding it…

Your support will not only get me to the Arctic, but will enable me to bring what I learn out there back home, to schools and communities, which will ultimately contribute to the creative and educational development of those participants and make me a better, more informed teacher. 

Thank you for your time and for supporting Making in Transit!




Other Ways You Can Help

Sharing this campaign via the Indiegogo share tools will be astronomically helpful! I need as much support as I can get to make this happen!

You can also follow how Making in Transit develops by visiting the Making in Transit website, and the making in transit Facebook page will serve as project diary.

Please visit my website to see more of my work, and my instagram and twitter accounts for more on what I'm up to.


Thank you so much!

Jennifer Crouch

These crafts will be used to record geological structures and monitor expedition resource consumption, specifically by means of; the ancient Incan Quipu and Inuit hand-carved tactile maps (such as the Ammasalik maps of Greenland). 

These crafts have been chosen because or their ability to navigate
space, record data, communicate, and help humans plan and organise their
lives. These incredible examples of human ingenuity demonstrate how craft
relates to resources and thus explores the relationship between
our environment and 'making'. 
In a world dominated by screen-based technology, the ability
of the Quipu and Inuit maps to serve as tactile data representation makes their
appeal to use as educational tools in interactive workshops both engaging and
powerful. I intend to explore the role of handmade technology and
(re)discover the relationships that can be formed with our environment through
making.
As well as enabling me to take part in this residency, raising funds
through this campaign will enable me to share my experience though an
exhibition and school workshops that explore subjects such as geography, design
and statistics.
A large part of the Making in Transit timeline 
occurs after I return from the Arctic Circle
Residency, in the form of a series of workshops run in London schools (at the
The Ellen Wilkinson School for Girls, Harris Academies and Notting Hill School).  
Conversations are also underway regarding workshops
with schools in Cardiff, Glasgow, Denmark, Sweden and Norway on my return
journey to London from Svalbard in order to engage more school students in the
project. Making in Transit will also culminate in a public exhibition
in Central London, which will be open to the public free of charge. 
All Making in Transit learning resources created
for the workshops will be made available for school teachers to use and adapt
free of charge on  TES.com (a learning resource archive used
by teachers). The Making in Transit resources will be of use for teachers of geography,
physics, mathematics, art and design, technology and engineering, and will be
adapted to be suitable for Key Stages 1–5. Please note: I am taking my own
time out of employment to carry out this work and will not receive any personal
financial gain. I am totally reliant on donors and other potential sources of
funding to complete this work. 


Who am I?My name is Jennifer Crouch, I am a school teacher, artist, lecturer and co-founder of the Art-Physics project Jiggling Atoms. I also work as current artist in residence at the UCL Centre for Advanced Biomedical Imaging (CABI) carrying out a long-term project about the relationship between craftsmanship and scientific research.  In addition to having exhibited artwork prolifically and internationally, I have also lectured at Central Saint Martins (where I am tutor on the course in Anatomical Drawing), Imperial College, Camberwell College of Arts, Bournemouth and Northampton University. I have a proven track record of running workshops, teaching school students and graduates, and organising successful exhibitions and public engagement events with organisations such as Jiggling Atoms. 
I also teach design
and technology in a secondary school and make artwork that explores science and
technology through craft, ceramics, workshops and pictorial representation. I
studied physics followed by Illustration at university and later trained as a medical
illustrator. Currently I am training to become a teacher with the School Direct 
training scheme and
completing my PGCE at Goldsmiths University – as learning underpins my artistic
work, it felt right to learn how to teach! 
What I Need & What You Get
I will only be able to take part
in the Arctic Circle Residency if I can raise enough money to make it there and
cover participation costs. I need to raise a total of £6,000. 
Travelling through the Arctic Circle, putting on an exhibition and
delivering educational workshops to schools are complicated affairs and
reaching my target will enable me to do all these things, covering:

Expedition participation on board the ship from our point of
     departure to the return point in Longyearbyen (30th September and
     19th October 2016).
Excursions on land in order to carry out essential practical work for
     the project.
Return train travel between London, Cardiff, Glasgow, Denmark,
     Sweden and Norway, and a return flight to Svalbard to enable visiting
     of destinations along the way for public engagement workshops in
     schools. 
All materials for workshops for use in the UK and abroad (simple
     portable carving tools, wood for carving and clay).
Exhibition costs and to cover talks at the exhibition given by
     expert guest speakers, who will discuss issues such as climate change,
     anthropology, the arctic ecosystem.

All donations will contribute
towards the expedition, whether I exceed or fall short
of my target. During the educational workshops students will be taught about
the Quipu and tactile carved maps and have a chance to create their own (from
soft materials such as soap bars or clay.) Their maps and Quipu will be used to
explore their own local environment and record resource use around them.
Beginning to engage with and compare our potential impact on our environment is
the first step towards understanding how to respond to change. The more
money I raise, the more people I can share this project with. 

So far, generous
supporters of Making in Transit include The Cube 
project space in East
London, who have kindly offered the use of their exhibition space to host the
Making in Transit exhibition from December 2016 to February 2017, free of
charge! This will enable visitors to see the work I will create in the Arctic,
meet experts and researchers, ask questions and express concerns about
important issues surrounding climate change. Below is an image of the entrance
of The Cube. I'm really excited about what this project could achieve, not only experiencing
the vast, cold Arctic and producing work there, but knowing that there is a platform
where this can be shared following this.  
Perks for donorsVarious ‘perks’ are available to donors, providing supporters with opportunities to own some of my artwork, in
addition to owning hand-carved maps, Quipu and other artefacts created during
the Arctic Circle residency. All contributions of financial assistance
are gratefully received, with all donors receiving regular updates on the
project via the project website as well as invites to the final exhibition.  

As well as creating limited edition prints, ornamental printed ceramic
tiles and commemorative plates especially for this campaign, other prints from  the Magic Calendar series and printed textiles 
are also available for donors to this
campaign.  




Above is a close-up of the Making in Transit riso print inspired by the Arctic landscape and geology which you can also select as a perk.Printed anatomical plates, as well as paintings and hand-painted ceramic pieces 
that were hired for use on the set of the  Paddington Bear film, are also up for grabs (if
you have seen the film, these paintings, drawings and plates are in the
background of the kitchen and bathroom scenes). 
Below are the Making in Transit commemorative ceramic tiles that you can also select as a perk! Six different designs available! 

One particular work of art I have made available
includes a piece called the ‘infinite landscape’ 
that was created for my second solo exhibition
in 2009, it consists of 9 different images that can be rearranged and connected
into 362,880 different combinations.  I am making a large range of my
works available as perks to encourage as many people to donate as possible, so
this is a good chance to own some of my work.
The above painting is available and is called Flatland: be patient for the world is broad and wide. This painting was exhibited in the prestigious 2012 Threadneedle Prize exhibition. Select the perk called Flatland for this one. Other paintings are also available as perks!


Risks and Challenges
Working full-time as a teacher in a secondary school in London is a
difficult but rewarding job; balancing this with my creative endeavours and
professional artistic practice is indeed a challenge, but one I am dedicated
to. I am passionate about bringing together art projects and education, and residency
schemes like this enable me to do this, uniting keys interests of mine such as data
representation, indigenous crafts and environmental issues, all of which have
an important ethical dimension in today’s world. It was indeed a challenge
getting a place on the residency, but now the next challenge is funding it…
Your support will not only get me to the Arctic, but will enable me to bring
what I learn out there back home, to schools and communities, which will
ultimately contribute to the creative and educational development of those
participants and make me a better, more informed teacher. 
Thank you for your time and for supporting Making in Transit!

Other Ways You Can HelpSharing this campaign via the Indiegogo share tools will be astronomically helpful! I need as much support as I can get to make this happen!You can also follow how Making in Transit develops by visiting the Making in Transit website, and the making in transit Facebook page will serve as project diary.Please visit my website to see more of my work, and my instagram and twitter accounts for more on what I'm up to.Thank you so much!Jennifer Crouch

story:
THE YOGA COLORING BOOK

ABOUT THIS PROJECT

One Year Subscription: 52 weeks of coloring pages.
 Delivered every Friday via email delivery.
  • Adult coloring pages
  • Downloadable file
  • Delivered weekly to your email address
  • New artwork weekly, 52 art works in all
  • First download will be available April 2016 or sooner!

This project is perfect for art therapy, classrooms, coloring groups and waiting rooms. Print out as many pages as you need at no extra cost. The coloring pages are suited to anyone from age 12 to 100+ 

Pages cannot be posted on sharing sites like Pinterest, etc. Artist maintains all copyrights. Images may not be resold. 

What I Need & What You Get

MY PROJECT IS TO FUND ENOUGH MONEY TO CREATE A DIGITAL  COLORING BOOK AND  IN THE FUTURE ALSO A HARD COPY BOOK.

SINCE I HAVE A DAY JOB, THIS PROJECT IS A SIDE PROJECT.

 IT TAKES TIME AND EXTRA EFFORT TO MAKE IT HAPPEN, TO MAKE THE BEST YOGA ILLUSTRATION BOOK ON THE MARKET.

 I STRIVE FOR THE BEST.

 I'M A MOTHER TO TOW WONDERFULL LITTLE GIRLS.

BASICLY THIS PROJECT IS MOSTLY UTILIZING MY TIME.

I DO NEED TO PRINT OUT SHEETS AND FOR THAT I NEED A GOOD PRINTER AND A BETTER SCANNER.

SO THIS IS IT. SHORT AND SIMPLE. THANK YOU



The first estimated digital delivering dates are:  

  • Page #1  Friday April 8
  •  Page #2 Friday April 15
  •  Page #3 Friday April 22
  • Page #4 Friday April 29
  • Risks & Challenges

I don't forsee any issues. The project is simple. I complete one detailed original coloring page weekly. This takes me anywhere from 4 to 5 hours. I then need to scan, edit and create a digital file of the drawing before emailing it out. I will keep you updated with regular progress reports.

thank you!
