story:
Short Summary


Hello everyone!

My name is Tudor Drambarean and I work for a Municipality in Romania called Alba Iulia (Transylvanian region).

The municipality is trying to support the local Jewish Community of Alba Iulia in order to help the conservation and preservation of the local Jewish Heritage which is very important for the long history of our city and for the history of the Jewish Community.

Short history of the Jewish Cemetery site:

The Jewish Cemetery from Alba Iulia is the oldest Cemetery in Transylvania, and one of the oldest in Romania. The first mentioning referring to the Cemetery date from the second part of the XVIII Century. The Cemetery was always positioned in the Old part of the city, near the historic Jewish neighborhood and at the outskirts of the Vauban Citadel Alba Carolina which was constructed in the early 18th Century when Transylvania came under Habsburg Empire rule.


The terrain of the cemetery was bought from the Municipality in 1764, although the Jewish Cemetery also appears in a city plan dating from 1752. The oldest plan of the cemetery, which opened the first burial register, contains the names of those who were buried in the initial area. The tomb of Chief Rabbi Ezekiel Paneth (1823-1845), who built the first synagogue of wall in Transylvania, was placed in its center. The Cemetery extended its borders over time due to donations made by some members of the Jewish community such as Moses and Joseph Mendel between 1874-1875. The funerary inscriptions in Hungarian and German language, and the stylistic changes of the tombstones date from the same period. In the early 20th century, the most prosperous families in the city have raised monumental tombs in the new section.

The Cemetery unfortunately lost its visibility and importance during and after the Second World War when most of the Jewish inhabitants of the city left the country. It remains one of the most important Jewish Cemeteries in Romania due to the large number of tombs and the architectural heritage present.

There is also a theory that the cemetery might have been moved due to
the construction of the large Vauban Citadel.

Municipality's role: 

One of the actions taken by the Municipality of Alba Iulia was to submit an application at the World Monuments Fund for the 2016 World Monuments Watch List. Unfortunately we were not successful with the application, however we are still determined to continue further and submit another application in 2017.

Another action taken recently was to produce a Video Documentary about the
Jewish Heritage in Alba Iulia called "Testimonies Carved in Stone" in order to raise awareness internationally about the importance of this site. A link to the film you can find bellow:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRdhkiudkb0

This campaign is very important due to the significance of the Jewish
heritage site. The Jewish Cemetery is one of the oldest in Transylvania and it
contains a lot of architectural monuments which are unique in Romania and even
in other parts of Europe. It is also very important since the local Jewish
Community is nowadays comprised of a small group of people (18) which
are the only remaining members of the local Jewish community of Alba
Iulia. In this regard, to lose these impressive monuments would mean no only a
loss for the Jewish Community of Alba Iulia or the city as a whole, but a loss
for European and international Jewish Heritage. Moreover, the four (4)
centuries old cemetery is just like an open air museum, revealing its vestiges
to visitors in different historic sequences from the 17th, 18th, 19th and 20th
century making it also unique in this regard.

Therefore the contributions raised through this campaign would
contribute enormously to the preservation and promotion of an important
landmark of Alba Iulia - the Jewish Cemetery - and would enable the city to strengthen again the links with an important international community which needs to be aware that Alba Iulia was once the Center of Jewish spiritual and social life in Transylvania.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The rehabilitation and preservation of the monuments within the Jewish
Cemetery represent a complex project which needs the combined efforts of
various experts from the municipality, local University, architecture
firms and from the Jewish Community itself.

The financial effort is by far the most important, although the most
difficult one to obtain, thus being the main reason for creating this
campaign.

Roughly the costs for the project would be the following:

These restoration costs have been calculated by officially recognized local Restaurateurs which have been working already in the Jewish Cemetery and which have an in-depth knowledge on the situation of the site.

Restoration Project estimated time: 24 months

PHASES:

Phase I-Survey and documentation of the site

Period 1 month

PHASE II-Public Tender for employing a restoration company

Period 2 months

Phase III-Stabilization, restoration and conservation works at the 4
Crypts

Period 12 months

Chapel, Rabi’s grave home, 700 funerary stones

Period 12 months

The restoration of the 4 Monumental Crypts’:

- Repairs of plasters, Opening of plasters for combating dampness, Treatments for combating dampness, Ornamental plasters, Repairs at architectural ornaments, Repairs at wooden joinery (doors, windows), Painting walls, Hydro-isolations for the bottom of the building, Repairs at cover, Repairs metal joinery

TOTAL COSTS: 130.311 lei/32.511,91$

The Chapel’s restoration:

- Repairs of inside plasters, Opening of plasters for combatting dampness,  Treatments applied for combatting dampness, Outside plasters, Repairs at inside sealing and walls, Outside repairs, Repairs at wooden joinery, Repairs at cover,  Gutters, downpipes, Hydro-isolations for the bottom of the building

TOTAL COSTS: 48.113,76 lei/12.004,13$

The restoration  of the Rabi’s grave home:

- Approximately same works apply as with the chapel although at a smaller
scale

TOTAL COSTS: 8.610,79 lei/2.148,35$

The restoration of 700 funerary stones:

- Cleaning off invading factors through chemical and mechanical factors
(biologic attack or salt deposits)

- Chemical Treatments applied for strengthening the stone

- Fixing of broken parts of the stone through chemical process

- Chemical and mechanic treatment for restoring the architectural and
ornamental details

- Chemical Treatment for strengthening the structure of the stones

- Waterproofing of the stone

TOTAL COSTS: 138.607,62 lei/34.581,88$

Phase IV-Arrangements of the Cemetery alleys, front yard, urban furniture
at the site

TOTAL COSTS: 154.130,24 lei/38.454,69$

Period 2 months

Phase V-Restoration of the main Gate

TOTAL COSTS: 14.430,78 lei/3.600,04$

Period 2 months

Phase VI-Restoration of the Cemetery’s fence

TOTAL COSTS: 193.246,78 lei/48.214,06$

Period 3 months

Phase VII-Promotion of the site

Period 2 months

TOTAL GENERAL COSTS: 687.450,97 lei / 171.515,42$ (February 2016
RON/Dollar conversion)

 

The site is unique in terms of monuments diversity and relevance. Members of
the Jewish Community say that its uniqueness goes far beyond our national
borders while its position in the city center shows that the Jewish
Community has always been at the heart of events in Alba Iulia city. 

The funding would be needed for the restoration works needed to preserve the
site. Furthermore, a lot of voluntary work will also be involved, such as
the organization of summer camps with students which will be working at the
site. 

It is important to mention that any donations received will be used by the Local Jewish Community itself as they know best what the needs are for the Jewish Cemetery. The Municipality is trying to support the campaign as much as possible since the community is not considerably numerous at present.

The amount stated above represents the total funding needed for rehabilitating the whole cemetery and about 700 of the 2000 existing stones (the oldest part of the cemetery) which is of course very substantial and not very easy to raise due to the site's low visibility. However any amount that will be obtained will be very useful for restoring at least part of the cemetery monuments such as: the 4 Monumental Crypts, the alleys, some of the Matzevas in a very bad state etc..

Alba Iulia Municipality would manage the proposed project due to its considerable experience in Projects’ management and implementation. The Municipality implemented in the last years numerous projects with European, national and international funding in order to restore the Vauban citadel Alba Carolina and to valorize the historic heritage within the citadel.

For more information on this please access: www.apulum.ro, http://turism.apulum.ro/

 

The Impact


The impact of the restoration and conservation project of the Jewish
Cemetery with all its heritage would be very important. Firstly all the
heritage comprised of the 4 crypts, 1 chapel, the Rabbi's grave house and the
over 700 tomb stones would be restored and preserved to a very good state of
conservation.

Secondly, the Jewish Cemetery would become an outdoor Museum of Jewish
history for the 60.000 inhabitants of Alba Iulia municipality, but also for the
over 400.000 visitors coming to the city each year which would also ensure the
sustainability of the site!

The visibility of the site would be greatly increased thus attracting an
important number of cultural tourists, while the site would be integrated into
the cultural touristic trails at national an international level. Nevertheless,
the site would enable the local Jewish community to reconnect with the rest of
the inhabitants of the city and would help this community to reintegrate into
the city life by raising awareness of its significant history and cultural
print on the evolution of the city. The project would also enable the international Jewish Community, very interested in practicing cultural and ecumenical tourism, to reconnect with one of the most important Jewish historic landmarks of Romania.

Last but not the least, the restoration project would also raise awareness
at national and international level through the valorization of an outstanding
architectural monument very important for the Romanian Jewish Community and
would  particularize the Jewish community in Alba Iulia among the
important historic Jewish communities in Europe and in the world.

Alba Iulia Municipality is the institution which would manage a restoration project and will commit for the project 30.000$/120.243 LEI (February 2016, RON/Dollar conversion) as matching Funds, should the project receive at least 141.515,42$ from the Campaign or other potential donors.

Moreover Alba Iulia Municipality is also committed to support and maintain
financially, logistically and administratively the sustainability of the Jewish
Cemetery after the project implementation, in partnership with the local Jewish
Association.

Alba Iulia has a substantial experience in implementing restoration projects
since during the last 7 years it has implemented numerous projects which
envisaged the restoration of the Citadel inside the city (the largest Vauban
Citadel in South-Eastern Europe).

For a list of projects implemented by the Municipality of Alba Iulia please see bellow:

- The Roman Castrum gate was rebuilt and it was inaugurated in 2010. Located
on the Route of the Three Fortifications, it is recognized as a unique target
in Europe. The value of the rehabilitation was 417.718,83 Euros.

- The Fifth Gate restoration costs amounted 589.998,35 Euros.
The project was funded through a grant from the Kingdom of Norway, Iceland and
Liechtenstein.

- The Fourth Gate of the city wall located near the two cathedrals,
Orthodox and Roman Catholic, hosts a tourist information center and an exhibition of the Citadel's monuments. It was completely restored as a result of a project
financed by the Ministry of Culture, Alba Iulia City Council and the United
Nations Development Program (UNDP), with a total value of 471.998,68 Euros.

- The most impressive of Vauban gates, The Third Gate (where you can
also find Horea's cell) was introduced to the tourist circuit in the spring of 2009 after more than a decade since the work for rehabilitation began. The total cost of
the rehabilitation works was up to 1.651.995,37 Euros.

- The Second Gate of the Citadel of Alba Iulia was inaugurated in 2009.
It was demolished in 1937 to allow the access of the heavy machinery to the place
where the Horea, Closca and Crisan Obelisk was built. The objective was restored using ancient photos and using parts of the old gate. The rehabilitation works amounted 519.198,55 Euros.

- The First Gate is located in the eastern part of the assembly and is
built as a triumphal arch provided with three openings. The restoration works amounted approximately 530.998,51 Euros.

- The project "Access routes, lightning and urban furniture
within the trenches of the Vauban fortress - South Route,  North Route, East
Route” had a total value  of 11.209.968,61 Euros, of which more
than 7.717.178,39 Euros were allocated by the European Union and the
Romanian Government.

- The project “The Rehabilitation of the historic center of Alba Iulia, Vauban
fortification - access roads, Exterior lighting and urban furniture. Interior
zone” having a total budget of17.281.203,76 Euros.

- “The Restoration and enhancement of Alba Carolina Citadel
access for the west side, Vauban Fortress,  Alba Iulia Municipality” project
had a total budget of 16.179.051,12 Euros of which the City Hall’s
contribution to the total value of the project was 3.001.993,28 Euros.

The Total amount invested through European and international
funding for the rehabilitation of the Vauban Citadel between 2009-2012 was
up to 48.852.131,78 EUROS.

Thus the experience acquired by the Municipality in the last years is
substantial and will make a significant difference in implementing a
restoration project within the Jewish Cemetery.

The Municipality is very committed to restoring and promoting the cultural
and architectural vestiges within the city premises in order to enrich the
touristic and cultural potential of the city. The Jewish culture is part of the
city's culture and history as it represents an integral part of the city's life
for over four (4) centuries.

In 2015 Alba Iulia Municipality submitted an application for 2020 European
Capital of Culture which even though was not successful still proves the city's
great ambitions for becoming a beacon of culture in the region.

 

Risks & Challenges


The first challenge is represented by the low visibility of the site making it virtually unknown both nationally and internationally. However this is the place where the first Jews officially settled in Transylvania. Historically and culturally this is very important since the first Rabbis were also settled here and from this place they managed the whole Jewish social and ecumenical/spiritual life, while being also the center place from where Jewish life started to flourish in Transylvania! 

The Jewish Cemetery in Alba Iulia represents not only the identity of the
Jewish community but also one of the identities of the city. It represents part
of the urban heritage which needs to be protected and conserved for the future.
The current main challenges to the Jewish Cemetery site are the low number of
Jewish members living in the city and even at County level (only about 40)
which leads to the difficult maintenance of the Cemetery, combined with the
lack of technical resources and lack of adequate funds necessary for the
preservation and conservation works. It is important to mention that at Alba
County level there are about 19 Jewish cemeteries and only about twice the
number of people from the Jewish community living here, making it impossible
financially and logistically for the Jewish community to address all the existing problems!

The Jewish Cemetery from Alba Iulia is by far the largest and most impressive
in the region and undoubtedly one of the most important in Romania.

For this reason, Alba Iulia Municipality would be very committed to support a restoration project of the Jewish Cemetery in Alba Iulia with its own technical experts and resources and to provide all the substantial expertise acquired during the last 7 years in the implementation of various important restoration projects, mainly with the Vauban Citadel Alba Carolina (http://turism.apulum.ro/).


Another challenge is represented by the degradation of the cemetery due to
natural factors (weather, humidity, drought, soil etc.) which has lead to the
degradation of the Jewish architectural heritage (please check the photos annexed to the campaign for more details in this regard). The degradation state of the monuments is from medium to severe which calls for complex restoration and conservation works which will have a substantial cost. Nevertheless, the
Municipality together with the local University and other local architects, stone restaurateurs, engineers, etc. are well committed and prepared to initiate a complex restoration project.

 Moreover, as mentioned previously, there is a low public awareness
about the importance of the local Jewish Cemetery of Alba Iulia among the
local and regional inhabitants although the local authorities are very determined in raising public awareness and in supporting the preservation and conservation of the Jewish Cemetery in order to increase its visibility and to transform the cemetery into a visitable place due to its architectural characteristics and strategic position in the center of the city.

Another challenge would be the fact that the site of the Jewish Cemetery
with all its monuments are not yet declared as an official historic monument
which unfortunately reduces significantly the funds received from the national
culture institutions in Romania and probably from else ware. This is further
complicated by the fact that the Cemetery is still used today, making it complicated to change the current status of the site. Nevertheless the site of the Jewish  cemetery is historically attested  making it one of the oldest of its type and among the most important in Transylvania.

The lack of funding opportunities needed to conserve the Jewish Cemetery has
lead to the degradation of the 4 crypts and the chapel in the Cemetery by excess of humidity coming from the earth; the severe degradation of over 700 old funerary stones affected by excess of humidity, stone deposit, growth of wild vegetation, while most of them being in an urgent need for restoration and conservation otherwise they will be unrepairable and eventually lost forever. Some of the funerary stones are unique in complexity of details and in what regards architectural significance and need urgent preservation works otherwise
they will be unrepairable and eventually lost forever.

Through this crowd funding campaign we hope that these challenges will be at least partially overcome and that the amount raised would be sufficient at least to ensure a stable condition for the monuments within the Jewish Cemetery. It is very important to achieve this outcome in order to ensure the continuation of our local Jewish Cultural heritage also for the generations to come, which need to know and to learn that in Alba Iulia there was the first officially recognized Jewish community in Transylvania, uninterrupted till today.

 

Other Ways You Can Help


Anyone can help just by sharing our campaign link and by viewing and
sharing our Video Documentary called "Testimonies Carved in
Stone": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRdhkiudkb0

*UPDATE: Anyone willing to support the campaign after its ending on the INDIEGOGO site can donate directly to the Bank account of the Jewish Community in Alba Iulia at the following account:

RO34RNCB0003037779620001
Bank name: BCR Alba Iulia
SWIFT RNCB RO BU
Account holder: Comunitatea evreilor

*************************************************** 

THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FOR ALL YOUR SUPPORT!
story_txt:
Short Summary

Hello everyone!
My name is Tudor Drambarean and I work for a Municipality in Romania called Alba Iulia (Transylvanian region).
The municipality is trying to support the local Jewish Community of Alba Iulia in order to help the conservation and preservation of the local Jewish Heritage which is very important for the long history of our city and for the history of the Jewish Community. 
Short history of the Jewish Cemetery site:
The Jewish Cemetery from Alba Iulia is the oldest Cemetery in Transylvania, and one of the oldest in Romania. The first mentioning referring to the Cemetery date from the second part of the XVIII Century. The Cemetery was always positioned in the Old part of the city, near the historic Jewish neighborhood and at the outskirts of the Vauban Citadel Alba Carolina which was constructed in the early 18th Century when Transylvania came under Habsburg Empire rule. 
The terrain of the cemetery was bought from the Municipality in 1764, although the Jewish Cemetery also appears in a city plan dating from 1752. The oldest plan of the cemetery, which opened the first burial register, contains the names of those who were buried in the initial area. The tomb of Chief Rabbi Ezekiel Paneth (1823-1845), who built the first synagogue of wall in Transylvania, was placed in its center. The Cemetery extended its borders over time due to donations made by some members of the Jewish community such as Moses and Joseph Mendel between 1874-1875. The funerary inscriptions in Hungarian and German language, and the stylistic changes of the tombstones date from the same period. In the early 20th century, the most prosperous families in the city have raised monumental tombs in the new section. 
The Cemetery unfortunately lost its visibility and importance during and after the Second World War when most of the Jewish inhabitants of the city left the country. It remains one of the most important Jewish Cemeteries in Romania due to the large number of tombs and the architectural heritage present.
There is also a theory that the cemetery might have been moved due tothe construction of the large Vauban Citadel.
Municipality's role: 
One of the actions taken by the Municipality of Alba Iulia was to submit an application at the World Monuments Fund for the 2016 World Monuments Watch List. Unfortunately we were not successful with the application, however we are still determined to continue further and submit another application in 2017.
Another action taken recently was to produce a Video Documentary about theJewish Heritage in Alba Iulia called "Testimonies Carved in Stone" in order to raise awareness internationally about the importance of this site. A link to the film you can find bellow:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRdhkiudkb0
This campaign is very important due to the significance of the Jewishheritage site. The Jewish Cemetery is one of the oldest in Transylvania and itcontains a lot of architectural monuments which are unique in Romania and evenin other parts of Europe. It is also very important since the local JewishCommunity is nowadays comprised of a small group of people (18) whichare the only remaining members of the local Jewish community of AlbaIulia. In this regard, to lose these impressive monuments would mean no only aloss for the Jewish Community of Alba Iulia or the city as a whole, but a lossfor European and international Jewish Heritage. Moreover, the four (4)centuries old cemetery is just like an open air museum, revealing its vestigesto visitors in different historic sequences from the 17th, 18th, 19th and 20thcentury making it also unique in this regard.
Therefore the contributions raised through this campaign wouldcontribute enormously to the preservation and promotion of an importantlandmark of Alba Iulia - the Jewish Cemetery - and would enable the city to strengthen again the links with an important international community which needs to be aware that Alba Iulia was once the Center of Jewish spiritual and social life in Transylvania.
 
What We Need & What You Get
 
The rehabilitation and preservation of the monuments within the JewishCemetery represent a complex project which needs the combined efforts ofvarious experts from the municipality, local University, architecturefirms and from the Jewish Community itself.
The financial effort is by far the most important, although the mostdifficult one to obtain, thus being the main reason for creating thiscampaign.
Roughly the costs for the project would be the following:
These restoration costs have been calculated by officially recognized local Restaurateurs which have been working already in the Jewish Cemetery and which have an in-depth knowledge on the situation of the site.
Restoration Project estimated time: 24 months
PHASES:
Phase I-Survey and documentation of the site 
Period 1 month
PHASE II-Public Tender for employing a restoration company 
Period 2 months
Phase III-Stabilization, restoration and conservation works at the 4Crypts
Period 12 monthsChapel, Rabi’s grave home, 700 funerary stones
Period 12 months
The restoration of the 4 Monumental Crypts’:
- Repairs of plasters, Opening of plasters for combating dampness, Treatments for combating dampness, Ornamental plasters, Repairs at architectural ornaments, Repairs at wooden joinery (doors, windows), Painting walls, Hydro-isolations for the bottom of the building, Repairs at cover, Repairs metal joinery 
TOTAL COSTS: 130.311 lei/32.511,91$
The Chapel’s restoration:
- Repairs of inside plasters, Opening of plasters for combatting dampness,  Treatments applied for combatting dampness, Outside plasters, Repairs at inside sealing and walls, Outside repairs, Repairs at wooden joinery, Repairs at cover,  Gutters, downpipes, Hydro-isolations for the bottom of the building 
TOTAL COSTS: 48.113,76 lei/12.004,13$
The restoration  of the Rabi’s grave home:
- Approximately same works apply as with the chapel although at a smallerscale
TOTAL COSTS: 8.610,79 lei/2.148,35$
The restoration of 700 funerary stones:
- Cleaning off invading factors through chemical and mechanical factors(biologic attack or salt deposits)
- Chemical Treatments applied for strengthening the stone
- Fixing of broken parts of the stone through chemical process
- Chemical and mechanic treatment for restoring the architectural andornamental details
- Chemical Treatment for strengthening the structure of the stones
- Waterproofing of the stone
TOTAL COSTS: 138.607,62 lei/34.581,88$
Phase IV-Arrangements of the Cemetery alleys, front yard, urban furnitureat the site
TOTAL COSTS: 154.130,24 lei/38.454,69$
Period 2 months
Phase V-Restoration of the main Gate
TOTAL COSTS: 14.430,78 lei/3.600,04$
Period 2 months
Phase VI-Restoration of the Cemetery’s fence
TOTAL COSTS: 193.246,78 lei/48.214,06$
Period 3 months
Phase VII-Promotion of the site
Period 2 months
TOTAL GENERAL COSTS: 687.450,97 lei / 171.515,42$ (February 2016RON/Dollar conversion)
 
The site is unique in terms of monuments diversity and relevance. Members ofthe Jewish Community say that its uniqueness goes far beyond our nationalborders while its position in the city center shows that the JewishCommunity has always been at the heart of events in Alba Iulia city. 
The funding would be needed for the restoration works needed to preserve thesite. Furthermore, a lot of voluntary work will also be involved, such asthe organization of summer camps with students which will be working at thesite. 
It is important to mention that any donations received will be used by the Local Jewish Community itself as they know best what the needs are for the Jewish Cemetery. The Municipality is trying to support the campaign as much as possible since the community is not considerably numerous at present.
The amount stated above represents the total funding needed for rehabilitating the whole cemetery and about 700 of the 2000 existing stones (the oldest part of the cemetery) which is of course very substantial and not very easy to raise due to the site's low visibility. However any amount that will be obtained will be very useful for restoring at least part of the cemetery monuments such as: the 4 Monumental Crypts, the alleys, some of the Matzevas in a very bad state etc..
Alba Iulia Municipality would manage the proposed project due to its considerable experience in Projects’ management and implementation. The Municipality implemented in the last years numerous projects with European, national and international funding in order to restore the Vauban citadel Alba Carolina and to valorize the historic heritage within the citadel.
For more information on this please access: www.apulum.ro, http://turism.apulum.ro/
 
The Impact

The impact of the restoration and conservation project of the JewishCemetery with all its heritage would be very important. Firstly all theheritage comprised of the 4 crypts, 1 chapel, the Rabbi's grave house and theover 700 tomb stones would be restored and preserved to a very good state ofconservation. 
Secondly, the Jewish Cemetery would become an outdoor Museum of Jewishhistory for the 60.000 inhabitants of Alba Iulia municipality, but also for theover 400.000 visitors coming to the city each year which would also ensure thesustainability of the site! 
The visibility of the site would be greatly increased thus attracting animportant number of cultural tourists, while the site would be integrated intothe cultural touristic trails at national an international level. Nevertheless,the site would enable the local Jewish community to reconnect with the rest ofthe inhabitants of the city and would help this community to reintegrate intothe city life by raising awareness of its significant history and culturalprint on the evolution of the city. The project would also enable the international Jewish Community, very interested in practicing cultural and ecumenical tourism, to reconnect with one of the most important Jewish historic landmarks of Romania.
Last but not the least, the restoration project would also raise awarenessat national and international level through the valorization of an outstandingarchitectural monument very important for the Romanian Jewish Community andwould  particularize the Jewish community in Alba Iulia among theimportant historic Jewish communities in Europe and in the world. 
Alba Iulia Municipality is the institution which would manage a restoration project and will commit for the project 30.000$/120.243 LEI (February 2016, RON/Dollar conversion) as matching Funds, should the project receive at least 141.515,42$ from the Campaign or other potential donors.
Moreover Alba Iulia Municipality is also committed to support and maintainfinancially, logistically and administratively the sustainability of the JewishCemetery after the project implementation, in partnership with the local JewishAssociation.
Alba Iulia has a substantial experience in implementing restoration projectssince during the last 7 years it has implemented numerous projects whichenvisaged the restoration of the Citadel inside the city (the largest VaubanCitadel in South-Eastern Europe). 
For a list of projects implemented by the Municipality of Alba Iulia please see bellow:
- The Roman Castrum gate was rebuilt and it was inaugurated in 2010. Locatedon the Route of the Three Fortifications, it is recognized as a unique targetin Europe. The value of the rehabilitation was 417.718,83 Euros.
- The Fifth Gate restoration costs amounted 589.998,35 Euros.The project was funded through a grant from the Kingdom of Norway, Iceland andLiechtenstein.
- The Fourth Gate of the city wall located near the two cathedrals,Orthodox and Roman Catholic, hosts a tourist information center and an exhibition of the Citadel's monuments. It was completely restored as a result of a projectfinanced by the Ministry of Culture, Alba Iulia City Council and the UnitedNations Development Program (UNDP), with a total value of 471.998,68 Euros.
- The most impressive of Vauban gates, The Third Gate (where you canalso find Horea's cell) was introduced to the tourist circuit in the spring of 2009 after more than a decade since the work for rehabilitation began. The total cost ofthe rehabilitation works was up to 1.651.995,37 Euros.
- The Second Gate of the Citadel of Alba Iulia was inaugurated in 2009.It was demolished in 1937 to allow the access of the heavy machinery to the placewhere the Horea, Closca and Crisan Obelisk was built. The objective was restored using ancient photos and using parts of the old gate. The rehabilitation works amounted 519.198,55 Euros. 
- The First Gate is located in the eastern part of the assembly and isbuilt as a triumphal arch provided with three openings. The restoration works amounted approximately 530.998,51 Euros.
- The project "Access routes, lightning and urban furniturewithin the trenches of the Vauban fortress - South Route,  North Route, EastRoute” had a total value  of 11.209.968,61 Euros, of which morethan 7.717.178,39 Euros were allocated by the European Union and theRomanian Government. 
- The project “The Rehabilitation of the historic center of Alba Iulia, Vauban fortification - access roads, Exterior lighting and urban furniture. Interiorzone” having a total budget of17.281.203,76 Euros. 
- “The Restoration and enhancement of Alba Carolina Citadelaccess for the west side, Vauban Fortress,  Alba Iulia Municipality” projecthad a total budget of 16.179.051,12 Euros of which the City Hall’scontribution to the total value of the project was 3.001.993,28 Euros.
The Total amount invested through European and internationalfunding for the rehabilitation of the Vauban Citadel between 2009-2012 wasup to 48.852.131,78 EUROS. 
Thus the experience acquired by the Municipality in the last years issubstantial and will make a significant difference in implementing arestoration project within the Jewish Cemetery. 
The Municipality is very committed to restoring and promoting the culturaland architectural vestiges within the city premises in order to enrich thetouristic and cultural potential of the city. The Jewish culture is part of thecity's culture and history as it represents an integral part of the city's lifefor over four (4) centuries.
In 2015 Alba Iulia Municipality submitted an application for 2020 EuropeanCapital of Culture which even though was not successful still proves the city'sgreat ambitions for becoming a beacon of culture in the region. 
 
Risks & Challenges

The first challenge is represented by the low visibility of the site making it virtually unknown both nationally and internationally. However this is the place where the first Jews officially settled in Transylvania. Historically and culturally this is very important since the first Rabbis were also settled here and from this place they managed the whole Jewish social and ecumenical/spiritual life, while being also the center place from where Jewish life started to flourish in Transylvania! 
The Jewish Cemetery in Alba Iulia represents not only the identity of theJewish community but also one of the identities of the city. It represents partof the urban heritage which needs to be protected and conserved for the future.The current main challenges to the Jewish Cemetery site are the low number ofJewish members living in the city and even at County level (only about 40)which leads to the difficult maintenance of the Cemetery, combined with thelack of technical resources and lack of adequate funds necessary for thepreservation and conservation works. It is important to mention that at AlbaCounty level there are about 19 Jewish cemeteries and only about twice thenumber of people from the Jewish community living here, making it impossiblefinancially and logistically for the Jewish community to address all the existing problems!The Jewish Cemetery from Alba Iulia is by far the largest and most impressivein the region and undoubtedly one of the most important in Romania.
For this reason, Alba Iulia Municipality would be very committed to support a restoration project of the Jewish Cemetery in Alba Iulia with its own technical experts and resources and to provide all the substantial expertise acquired during the last 7 years in the implementation of various important restoration projects, mainly with the Vauban Citadel Alba Carolina (http://turism.apulum.ro/).
Another challenge is represented by the degradation of the cemetery due tonatural factors (weather, humidity, drought, soil etc.) which has lead to thedegradation of the Jewish architectural heritage (please check the photos annexed to the campaign for more details in this regard). The degradation state of the monuments is from medium to severe which calls for complex restoration and conservation works which will have a substantial cost. Nevertheless, theMunicipality together with the local University and other local architects, stone restaurateurs, engineers, etc. are well committed and prepared to initiate a complex restoration project.
 Moreover, as mentioned previously, there is a low public awarenessabout the importance of the local Jewish Cemetery of Alba Iulia among thelocal and regional inhabitants although the local authorities are very determined in raising public awareness and in supporting the preservation and conservation of the Jewish Cemetery in order to increase its visibility and to transform the cemetery into a visitable place due to its architectural characteristics and strategic position in the center of the city. 
Another challenge would be the fact that the site of the Jewish Cemeterywith all its monuments are not yet declared as an official historic monumentwhich unfortunately reduces significantly the funds received from the nationalculture institutions in Romania and probably from else ware. This is furthercomplicated by the fact that the Cemetery is still used today, making it complicated to change the current status of the site. Nevertheless the site of the Jewish  cemetery is historically attested  making it one of the oldest of its type and among the most important in Transylvania.
The lack of funding opportunities needed to conserve the Jewish Cemetery haslead to the degradation of the 4 crypts and the chapel in the Cemetery by excess of humidity coming from the earth; the severe degradation of over 700 old funerary stones affected by excess of humidity, stone deposit, growth of wild vegetation, while most of them being in an urgent need for restoration and conservation otherwise they will be unrepairable and eventually lost forever. Some of the funerary stones are unique in complexity of details and in what regards architectural significance and need urgent preservation works otherwisethey will be unrepairable and eventually lost forever. 
Through this crowd funding campaign we hope that these challenges will be at least partially overcome and that the amount raised would be sufficient at least to ensure a stable condition for the monuments within the Jewish Cemetery. It is very important to achieve this outcome in order to ensure the continuation of our local Jewish Cultural heritage also for the generations to come, which need to know and to learn that in Alba Iulia there was the first officially recognized Jewish community in Transylvania, uninterrupted till today. 
 
Other Ways You Can Help

Anyone can help just by sharing our campaign link and by viewing andsharing our Video Documentary called "Testimonies Carved inStone": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YRdhkiudkb0
*UPDATE: Anyone willing to support the campaign after its ending on the INDIEGOGO site can donate directly to the Bank account of the Jewish Community in Alba Iulia at the following account:
RO34RNCB0003037779620001Bank name: BCR Alba IuliaSWIFT RNCB RO BUAccount holder: Comunitatea evreilor*************************************************** 
THANK YOU IN ADVANCE FOR ALL YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Perception and Proxemics

Have you ever thought about an audience member? An audience member and their role as an audience member? How much impact do they have on a work of art; a painting, a theatre performance or a music concert? Does it matter how close they stand, what their relationship with the people or objects involved are, or even how they were brought up as a child? 

Proxemics is the branch of knowledge that deals with the amount of space that people feel it is necessary to set between themselves and others. 

Perception is the ability to see, hear, or become aware of something through the senses.

How does proxemics (both physical and mental) affect your perception of something?

That's what I want to know.

 

Who is Andrea van der Kuil?

I am a 23-year old, Johannesburg (South African) born woman, with a dutch family and a love for Irish dancing and the arts.

My grandparents were all born in the Netherlands and all moved to South Africa after WWII. On my father's side, there are four children and on my mother's side there are three. Our family makes up a part of the dutch community in Johannesburg and we have kept our grandparents' origin as part of our lives. We speak dutch, eat dutch and live dutch. Despite this rich Dutch background, my brother, many of my cousins and I were brought up English, with dutch as a second language.

I have just graduated from Wits University with a BA Performing and Visual Arts degree. My subjects within this degree included Production Design, Physical Theatre, Musical Theatre and English. I did everything from building sets and making costumes as a first year crew member, to stage managing productions, to designing sets and costumes as a designer, to performing in various productions as an actor and dancer.

As a theatre designer, I work with directors, theatre makers and facilitators to make their visions and ideas become a reality on stage. What I don't often get the chance of doing, however, is directing and facilitating my own visions and ideas. Fortunately, I have been accepted to a design residency after submitting a project proposal. The residency will consist of me going to Berlin for two months and creating a work supported by a concept of my own design.

Although I do not expect to make all of this money, I assure you that the money donated to this cause will go a long way in supporting this project and most certainly a long way in appreciation.

 

More about the project...

There are two instances that occurred during my University career that led me to this point in my life. These two points are my points of departure. 

When I was in second year we were tasked with creating an installation that had to be a reaction to a specific space. We could choose the space we wanted to create our work in; one that we thought had a potentially meta characteristic. I chose one of the girls bathroom at Wits; the theatre bathroom to be exact.​

The reason I chose this bathroom was two-fold. Firstly, because of all of it's mirrors. It is quite a voyeuristic space and one can't stand in any corner of the bathroom without being seen by someone else standing in a completely opposing corner. The second reason was due to the worry/myth of 'spending too much time in the bathroom'. In my time spent at Wits University I had found that many girls, not only in that bathroom alone, had a strange obsession with getting in and out of the bathroom as quickly as possible; not spending 'too long' in the bathroom. This misconception around being in the bathroom extends to taking the time to look in the mirror. Does looking in the mirror make you vain?

Thus, my objective with my installation was to 1.) heighten the voyeuristic nature of the space and 2.) disrupt the familiar space in order to have those who went in really look and reevaluate the space. I wanted to bring an awareness to the space to those who walked in.

 

My second point of departure has to do with the research project I did in my honours year. The research project was entitled 'Inside/Outside Status Regarding Proxemics and Distance'. The project consisted of a practical production and a theoretical research paper. We could write our final paper on any concept/idea we wanted to, obviously relating/reflecting to the project we had completed. My paper dealt with the effects that physical, mental and emotional space had on a viewer in relation to a work of art.

I was very successful in the initial submissions of both these projects and believe that taken further I will be even more successful in making an impact on questions asked by many theatre practitioners.

 

How much money and why?

This brings me to the amalgamation of these two projects into my design residency project in Berlin. My residency will begin on the first of November and thus I have roughly three months to gather a lot of money to pay for a lot of various aspects of my trip. 

Let me break it down:

Accommodation and studio space: R40000 ($2772,19​)

A flight to Berlin: R14000 ($970,26)

Food for two months: R20000 ($1386,09​​)

Materials to make my installation: R13000 ($693,05​)

Thus I need R87000 ($6060,18)

That's a lot of money, and the majority of the money is due to the exchange rate.

 

As you can see, I have a far way to go. I implore you to support me. I have never had an opportunity to show what I can do on such a large platform before and I think that this would be an amazing launching pad for someone who has just graduated. I have no doubt that the impact it will have on my life will be inexplicable!

I would love and greatly appreciate your support. And if it's not money, scream shout and post about this campaign. Tell friends, friends of friends and the world! Indiegogo has an array of share tools to make it easier for you to make it easier for me.

Thank you.

story:
For the Culture

This film is relevant to the artistic and culinary culture of Chicago's South Side, including the importance of family and food to Black Chicago's identity.

Eric Walker: Director, Co-Screenwriter, and Co-Producer

I am a director and actor focused on telling stories that reflect the true culture of our urban communities.

Andre Richardson Hogan II: Co-Screenwriter, Co-Producer

I am a published poet and produced playwright and screenwriter. Upon receiving a BFA in Liberal Arts in Columbia College, Chicago, “The Hot Wing Special” is based on a stage play of mine and of the same title.

Why This Film is Important

The Hot Wing Special shows how generations can essentially bridge the communication gap present in our culture.We want to produce a modern love story representing today’s community on a sociocultural level.

We Appreciate Your Time and Financial Support!

As a contributor, you will support creative expression for and by our communities, demonstrating the power of circulating the black dollar.

story:
What is this?

Hi. My name is Bobby. I'm the maker of the shiny things at Dark Side Customs. I've been making jewelry since 1999. This particular business has been up and running since 2009. It's my way of putting handmade, geek-inspired jewelry and accessories out into the world. 


Many people that know me also know that I wear kilts quite often. I love them. They're super comfortable. They also fit the vibe of the conventions and faires where you're most likely to find me hocking my wares. My big idea at the moment... Kilt Pins. Not just any kilts pins. Geeky Kilt Pins. 

The Kilt Pin is a traditional, functional, and cool part of wearing a kilt. It keeps your kilt from flapping in the breeze and showing of things you may not want the general public to see. 

Your standard Kilt Pin (like the one pictured) is quite the cool bit of kit for your kilt. But I work with geeks. They like a bit more... Geekery. That's where I come in. That's where you come in.

Because I work with small, simple hand tools, making these pins could get to be quite a bit pricey. I have, however, found a tool that will cut the work time immensely. It will allow me to keep my prices low. That will allow interested parties to be able to afford my work. No hesitation. That is exactly what I want. 

I've been the guy that couldn't afford anything at a convention or faire. These are my people. I cater to them.

What We Need & What You Get.

Break it down for folks in more detail:

The tool I need to do this work is a bit on the pricey side. It's a mini fusion welder. Along with the tool, I'll need a few necessary accessories to be sure I can move from one job to the next with ease.

It won't just be Kilt Pins. It will also be earrings I have been afraid to try for fear of damaging or destroying delicate and expensive materials with a torch. Tie tacks. Cravat Pins. Brooches. Etc. You can even feel free to give your input. Have a design in mind? I love a challenge. Let's do this.  

For funding this campaign, I'll be giving you the first success. Those earrings, tie tacks, Kilt Pins... yup. You're totally getting some. I'll be including a handwritten thank you note with each perk I send out. You deserve nothing less. You'll be helping me get one step closer to moving this business out of the house (and my wife's hair) and into the shop I've been dreaming of. But that's a later campaign.

If I don't happen to make all the money needed, I'll still be putting the money away to save for this tool and the accessories. I'll still be sending out the handwritten thank you notes. They will simply include a message about why you might have to wait a bit longer for your perks. If I get close enough, I'll just get the tool I need for the one project. I can wait for the accessories for the others. But I'm not going to dwell on the negative.

Why, Bobby?

If you really want to know why I'm doing this...

I have a silly dream of opening my own store one day. I don't want to owe a penny to a bank if I can help it. This is a baby step.

I want to give my fellow geeks (and anyone that loves handmade jewelry and accessories) the type of quality they deserve. Better. I want to walk around the events I'm working and feel proud to see my items doing their job. 

Kilts are going mainstream. Now I have a little something extra to contribute to the world. I've worked in fashion for years. But now I can be a real part of it.

That's Easy. Right? 

No WAY!!! I'm still making all this stuff by hand. 

  • I'm designing it. 
  • I'm building it. 
  • I'm photographing it. 
  • I'm writing copy for it. 
  • I'm marketing it. 
  • I'm praying I can reach my audience. 
  • I'm doing it all again.

Why put myself through that? Because it's worth it. I'm not the type that gives up. It's hard? Fine. So am I.

What if you can't contribute funds?

No worries. You can still help in a big way. Share this campaign with your friends. Ask folks you know to get the word out and make some noise about the campaign. We all know a couple of weird people. Right? This could be right up their alley. 

"You don't need a penny to make a difference. Just a heart." 
(Me. Just now.)
story_txt:
What is this? Hi. My name is Bobby. I'm the maker of the shiny things at Dark Side Customs. I've been making jewelry since 1999. This particular business has been up and running since 2009. It's my way of putting handmade, geek-inspired jewelry and accessories out into the world. 



Many people that know me also know that I wear kilts quite often. I love them. They're super comfortable. They also fit the vibe of the conventions and faires where you're most likely to find me hocking my wares. My big idea at the moment... Kilt Pins. Not just any kilts pins. Geeky Kilt Pins. 
The Kilt Pin is a traditional, functional, and cool part of wearing a kilt. It keeps your kilt from flapping in the breeze and showing of things you may not want the general public to see. 

Your standard Kilt Pin (like the one pictured) is quite the cool bit of kit for your kilt. But I work with geeks. They like a bit more... Geekery. That's where I come in. That's where you come in.
Because I work with small, simple hand tools, making these pins could get to be quite a bit pricey. I have, however, found a tool that will cut the work time immensely. It will allow me to keep my prices low. That will allow interested parties to be able to afford my work. No hesitation. That is exactly what I want. 
I've been the guy that couldn't afford anything at a convention or faire. These are my people. I cater to them.


What We Need & What You Get.
 Break it down for folks in more detail:
The tool I need to do this work is a bit on the pricey side. It's a mini fusion welder. Along with the tool, I'll need a few necessary accessories to be sure I can move from one job to the next with ease.
It won't just be Kilt Pins. It will also be earrings I have been afraid to try for fear of damaging or destroying delicate and expensive materials with a torch. Tie tacks. Cravat Pins. Brooches. Etc. You can even feel free to give your input. Have a design in mind? I love a challenge. Let's do this.  
For funding this campaign, I'll be giving you the first success. Those earrings, tie tacks, Kilt Pins... yup. You're totally getting some. I'll be including a handwritten thank you note with each perk I send out. You deserve nothing less. You'll be helping me get one step closer to moving this business out of the house (and my wife's hair) and into the shop I've been dreaming of. But that's a later campaign.
If I don't happen to make all the money needed, I'll still be putting the money away to save for this tool and the accessories. I'll still be sending out the handwritten thank you notes. They will simply include a message about why you might have to wait a bit longer for your perks. If I get close enough, I'll just get the tool I need for the one project. I can wait for the accessories for the others. But I'm not going to dwell on the negative.   Why, Bobby? If you really want to know why I'm doing this...
I have a silly dream of opening my own store one day. I don't want to owe a penny to a bank if I can help it. This is a baby step.
I want to give my fellow geeks (and anyone that loves handmade jewelry and accessories) the type of quality they deserve. Better. I want to walk around the events I'm working and feel proud to see my items doing their job. 
Kilts are going mainstream. Now I have a little something extra to contribute to the world. I've worked in fashion for years. But now I can be a real part of it.



That's Easy. Right? 

No WAY!!! I'm still making all this stuff by hand. 



I'm designing it. 
I'm building it. 
I'm photographing it. 
I'm writing copy for it. 
I'm marketing it. 
I'm praying I can reach my audience. 

I'm doing it all again.


Why put myself through that? Because it's worth it. I'm not the type that gives up. It's hard? Fine. So am I.
    What if you can't contribute funds?
No worries. You can still help in a big way. Share this campaign with your friends. Ask folks you know to get the word out and make some noise about the campaign. We all know a couple of weird people. Right? This could be right up their alley.   "You don't need a penny to make a difference. Just a heart." (Me. Just now.)

We at RVC productions are very excited that you've scrolled thus far through our hopeful indiegogo fund raiser.  For years artist composer author Rossi V Charmoli (RVC) bled for underground musical art scenes across the United States, NEVER selling materials (not once) only gifting them to happy art lovers! While playing music with extremely gifted artists the idea for a large tour has popped up over numerous talks of our future. Everyone thought now was the right hour that we'd search for those who'd help us reach a wider audience through the material production of our artistic efforts on a huge tour!!!!  Independently Rossi' produced fifty plus original materials ready for mass physical distribution though a tour that encompasses nearly every venue of media publication. When you donate you'll receive the physical copies of Original Titles; Indie Group WEN albums & videos, Les Enfants song Trilogy, free jazz video & record Fil,  Piano Voice records Hu Tu Vu & Bla Gre Whi, Phontazia Sungphony, Oasi musical oil paints, Poetical imagery books EMATRE, GEMATRE, REMATRE, TREMATRE, Graphic novel Yori, picture book Tomorrow, watercolor vook Love Field, ink book Loons, Comic Shoegum, Feature length film !2|!2 & !2|2! with short merry and physical games tip tap top plus square up!!!! Again NEVER has RVC productions sold art pieces for profit, we'd love if you'll cover publication cost so we may share every part of it!!!! 

                                       The goal of $140,000 gives us the dough for lovely pizza pie wheels!

     Hu Tu Vu & Bla Gre Whi             -      7,000

    Oasi DVD                                           -      2,000

      We are very glad you've chosen us for your investment! Let's talk more soon! 

    honestly,

                RVC

story:
FORT LUMINA


                                 SPUTNIK


WHAT WE DO

 We handcraft Semi Sculptured Table Lamps.
 This lamp is 99% handmade, all the materials are hand-cut, shaped, polished,  soldered and finished. No two lamps are the same, each has its own  personality and character. Every step is meticulously done, each lamp is a  work of art intended to illuminate your room and brighten  up your evenings.
 I have been an artist most of my life, I love to draw and paint. About 3 years ago  I tried to combine art and electronics. I was really amazed by Light Emitting  Diodes or LEDs and its many applications. I have been experimenting how to  best use it and make the design unique at the same time. Luckily I came up  with a beautiful organic design using the combination of LEDs, light medium  like acrylic and most importantly copper. The natural beauty of copper blends  well with the table lamp concept as it also serves as a metal sculpture on the  table. Shiny or patina copper is always best for metal sculpture.  
 Table lamps doesn't only illuminates our rooms but also gives us the feeling of  comfort and a relaxed atmosphere. So I made my table lamps desirable  and  unique giving it a little organic vintage effect with the use of copper.


WHAT WE NEED


 Full funding for this project is around $5,000. The money that will be raised from  this campaign will go to the materials and better tools for making lamps.  A portion of the fund will go to developing a small home workshop to  assist  other family members earn a living.
 Working 9 to 5 doesn't give me the resources to build lamps that's why I'm asking for your support to raise funds that will enable me to share this  wonderful piece of art to all who desire. Since I'm just starting it takes about a  day to finish two units. Hopefully I will do much better using the right tools.

 

OUR TEAM 

 Me and my wife will start everything based on our career backgrounds, we are    both teachers before. I will cover the electronics and art side while my wife and  possibly  my son will assist in the basic production process, packing and  shipping. I'm  presently working on completing all the prototypes for the perks.


  WHAT'S BEHIND IT

   FORT LUMINA

   THIS UNIQUE TABLE LAMP IS DELICATELY AND INTRICATELY MADE USING    RAW MATERIALS SUCH AS COPPER WIRES, COPPER CLAD, LEDS, AND              PLASTIC LIGHT MEDIA. COPPER IS THE DESIGN BASE AND ACRYLIC AND        LIGHT IS THE CENTER PIECE. THE INSPIRATION BEHIND THE DESIGN IS A        FORTRESS MADE OF CRYSTAL ILLUMINATED FROM WITHIN.THE                          REFLECTIONS ARE CONCENTRATED WITHIN THE FORT INDICATING A                STRONG FEELING OR POWER COMING FROM THE LIGHT.
    SCULPTED  COPPER FORMS THE BASE AND ALSO SURROUNDS THE                 ENTIRE LIGHT DISPLAY. ALMOST IN ITS RAW FORM IT REPRESENTS                   EARTH FROM WHICH THE METAL CAME FROM.

 

 

 

                                                            FORT LUMINA


 

 

  

                                                               SPUTNIK

   

 INSPIRED BY THE THE RUSSIAN ARTIFICIAL EARTH SATELLITE, THIS                  ILLUMINATED SPHERE WILL ADD CLASS AND UNIQUENESS TO ANY ROOM.    COPPER IS THE DESIGN BASE AND ACRYLIC AND LIGHT IS THE CENTER          PIECE. THE SPHERE REPRESENTS THE MOON THAT RETAINS A CERTAIN          GLOW EVEN WHEN LIGHTS ARE OUT. IT RESTS ON A NEST SUPPORTED BY    A COPPER ROD.


   PERPETUAL POCKET LIGHT

   THESE CUTE LIGHTS WILL ALMOST SHINE FOREVER. FLIP, CHARGE, LIGHT,     LIGHT, LIGHT, REPEAT. ENCASED IN SCULPTED COPPER WIRE, IT COMES       IN 3 DESIRABLE COLORS (Green, Red, & Blue) AND WATER IS RESISTANT.    


     

    OTHER WAYS YOU CAN SHOW YOUR SUPPORT

    Please share our campaign with people whom you think may be interested in       our Art Lamps. We are open to all questions, comments and suggestions.             Just   reach us and let us know. Share email addresses of friends with us and       we can send them a direct   invitation to check out our campaign.

    Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/lester.delacruz.7737

story:
Ninjaprints

Ninjaprints was set up over a decade ago as my brand for my creative outlet and was always designed to be a flexible and far reaching venture, over the last 10 years I have established myself as a well regarded photographer as well as a dedicated creative and supporter of emerging artists, some years back we also expanded into printing services and are looking to further increase our reach and seize a key opportunity.

Many of you who are likely to be viewing this will already be aware of my photographic and print work due to the nature of social media and friend circles, you will also know that I have never run any such fund raiser before and that I have never really been a huge supporter of the over use of such fund sourcing methods that seems prevalent in today's society.

I have tried to come up with a solution that allows this fund raiser to garner genuine interest and raise the funds it needs whilst at the same time making sure it offers valid reasons for people to contribute and actually provide benefits that go some way to matching their contributions whilst not hindering any launch.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Following is a rough breakdown of what I need to raise and cover along with how it will be used and what will happen if target is exceeded or not reached.

  • New large format Epson printer with roll feed £1800
  • A3/A4 high res flatbed scanner with potential for negative scanning £500
  • Paper cutter / trimmer £120
  • New desk £150

Initial funds will be solely focused on getting a secondary large format printer in place to ensure downtime is kept to a minimum and to increase the rate we can output jobs whilst keeping overall costs down by not having to force ink changes between media types at a heavy price.

Having a secondary printer is vital to the current work as any problems, faults with the main one will prove catastrophic at this stage.

Further funds will be allocated to repairing / replacing my current warped and old desk space so I have a large, flat surface to work with for the jobs that require it and obtaining a high end paper cutter will be much needed for handling large prints and complex pieces that need trimming to size, at present this is all done by hand which is adequate but not as accurate as I need.

Final main targets would be to obtain a high resolution flatbed scanner for processing images and negatives in order to be able to offer print services for conventional photographers and illustrators.

Any excess funds will be used to procure storage space and shelving for paper and inks and if enough is raised a  A3+ fine art printer to act as a dedicated label printer, these will further be upgraded with refillable ink systems.  Should the target be very much exceeded I will look to obtain office space locally and a workstation for use there.

If targets are not reached funds will be put aside to use towards the main targets in any place, business is steadily coming in at an increasing rate and likely some of the goalposts will be reachable within a few months.

Rewards for contributions will be offered to all who pay into the campaign, vouchers (digital or physical) will be provided to cover printing work to the value of your contribution which can be redeemed for physical prints once we are set up with the new equipment, or with the current equipment if targets are not reached.  This method allows us to basically be selling a service in advance that will allow you to reclaim your value from the print lab in physical goods once we are set up and running.
 

The Impact

All funds raised will have a huge impact on the overall business, right now work is coming in thick and fast and I am struggling to keep on top of it, but the volumes being output will start to take their toll on the printing equipment and with nothing to fall back on if something breaks or fails it is not an ideal situation, having backup and secondary equipment is vital to being able to offer a reliable service and also balance the workflow.

Formally launching the fine art and photographic printing service alongside the labels is also a brilliant opportunity to expand reach and target audience, the equipment is already in use and expanding the market is a reliable way to increase profits, but to do so we need to ensure equipment is up to the job and supported by the tools required to provide an excellent service along with the space to make it work.

Risks & Challenges

Right now the main risks are very much in the form of equipment failure, should something suffer a fault now there is no backup in place and no means to continue developing and expanding the business and its reach.

Timing is also critical, other businesses dealing with the specific label industry I am targeting have recently been shedding business due to poor customer service and quality, the window is now and I need to seize it as fast as I can before it starts to close.

I have been printing for some years now and am rapidly learning new methods and techniques to create fantastic quality work across a range out areas, every new method or media is a learning curve and sometimes incredibly tricky, but the business is there and the market is ripe for a business like Ninjaprints to make a real strong impact with the current timing.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I utterly appreciate the lack of appeal crowdfunding can have to many people, myself included, so I have tried to keep this to a minimum of scrounging and am seeking to use this in whatever form it takes to push my small business forward as hard as I can after over a decade of seeking the kind of opportunities now showing their faces.

Everyone has different mindsets and circumstances and do not feel bad if you cannot contribute or do not wish to, but please do share this fundraiser for me, every little helps and goes a long way towards boosting Ninjaprints into something that can develop more rapidly and without constant worry.

Many thanks for taking the time to read, ponder and maybe even contribute.

 

Henry

The Impact
All funds raised will have a huge impact on the overall business, right now work is coming in thick and fast and I am struggling to keep on top of it, but the volumes being output will start to take their toll on the printing equipment and with nothing to fall back on if something breaks or fails it is not an ideal situation, having backup and secondary equipment is vital to being able to offer a reliable service and also balance the workflow.
Formally launching the fine art and photographic printing service alongside the labels is also a brilliant opportunity to expand reach and target audience, the equipment is already in use and expanding the market is a reliable way to increase profits, but to do so we need to ensure equipment is up to the job and supported by the tools required to provide an excellent service along with the space to make it work.

Risks & Challenges
Right now the main risks are very much in the form of equipment failure, should something suffer a fault now there is no backup in place and no means to continue developing and expanding the business and its reach.
Timing is also critical, other businesses dealing with the specific label industry I am targeting have recently been shedding business due to poor customer service and quality, the window is now and I need to seize it as fast as I can before it starts to close.I have been printing for some years now and am rapidly learning new methods and techniques to create fantastic quality work across a range out areas, every new method or media is a learning curve and sometimes incredibly tricky, but the business is there and the market is ripe for a business like Ninjaprints to make a real strong impact with the current timing.
 

Other Ways You Can Help
I utterly appreciate the lack of appeal crowdfunding can have to many people, myself included, so I have tried to keep this to a minimum of scrounging and am seeking to use this in whatever form it takes to push my small business forward as hard as I can after over a decade of seeking the kind of opportunities now showing their faces.Everyone has different mindsets and circumstances and do not feel bad if you cannot contribute or do not wish to, but please do share this fundraiser for me, every little helps and goes a long way towards boosting Ninjaprints into something that can develop more rapidly and without constant worry.
Many thanks for taking the time to read, ponder and maybe even contribute.
 
Henry

story:
Short Summary

Hi Guys, my name is Aleko and I am Youtube Magician. My Channel is called Tricklandia. I do lot's of Tutorial videos on different kinds of Magic Tricks.  I was always specially passionate about playing cards and I always wanted to have my own custom version of cards, that's why, about a year ago I've decided to create one. After countless hours of hard work and dedication I am proud to introduce Piramida Playing Cards, equipped with Built in Marking System and two Gaff cards. The Goal was to create a tool, a perfect helper, to conquer the impossible. A Superior Marking System combined with Luxury Design allows the artists to perform like never before. With Piramida Cards you can create real miracles, amaze people with stunning effects, which are impossible to do with the regular Decks of Cards. Piramida Cards will be printed by  Expert Playing Card Co (EPCC), On the highest quality stock available,  to provide the smoothest spreads, fans, and shuffles. Piramida Cards are Borderless and come in two shades BLACK and RED plus Limited Edition Piramida Desert with White Borders. All Piramida Decks come with beautiful Silver - Foiled and Embossed Tuck Cases.

Every Piramida deck contains 57 Cards, including 2 Jokers and 2 Gaff Cards ( 1x Double Backer and 1 x Double Facer ) and 1 x Sponsor Card.

 The Cost of Piramida Black is $10

The Cost of Piramida Red Deck is $10

Borederless Design Creates strong Blending Effect, which helps the performer to do Sleights easier.

The Tuck Boxes will be Silver Foiled and Embossed.

With Piramida Cards you can create stunning effects which are not possible with the regular deck of cards.

Limited Addition  Piramida Desert

Piramida Desert comes in true color of Desert with White Borders, it is also equipped with Built in Marking System and Gaff Cards ( Double Backer and Double Facer ).  Limited Edition Piramida Desert Decks are all Indiegogo Exclusive. They will not be sold after this Campaign ends. The Cost of each Piramida Desert Deck is $15 and it's Limited to 6 Decks per Backer. Limited Edition Decks will be NUMBERED !!! 

Custom Faces

The faces include custom fonts, pips, court cards, Ace of Spades and Jokers. Everything about Piramida Cards is Custom.

The idea of Joker represents all the obstacles of life, unfairness and humiliation happening around us every day.

Risks & Challenges

The only challenge is getting enough funding to get the decks printed. The Expert Playing Card Company ( EPCC )requires a minimum order of 1000 decks. But because I have three different Shades ( Black, Red and Desert ) it means that I am required to print minimum 3000 decks, This is large amount of money, which is why I am asking for your support in this Indiegogo campaign.

Once I have the funds I will be ready to print. Your rewards will be sent to you as soon as production is complete, which I expect to be in May of 2018 (hopefully sooner). 

 Every Dollar counts. I already have $12000 for this project but I need little more to fully fund  it. Thank you very much for your Support.

story:
The Journey

The AromAtom journey will take you on a tour of our Solar System and beyond, stopping at places such as our Moon, Mars, Jupiter, comets and asteroids, the rings of Saturn and the spiral arms of the Milky Way, to explore their surfaces, atmospheres and histories.

At each “station” you will be surrounded by images of the place where you are, and will be provided with a  number of things to smell, which will give an approximation of what being in that planet or part of the galaxy might be like. As you smell, you can read or hear about the odours you are smelling, and also how and why those odours might be found at different locations in space. Basic chemistry, astronomy, physics and geology concepts are weaved into the story to help you form a realistic picture of the part of space where you are and give context to your experience. Many of the smells will be strange or even alien to you, but before moving on to the next “station”, an artistic interpretation of the smell of the planet will also be provided, and this one will be much nicer!

The exhibition ends with a scent that combines the various stages of the AromAtom journey into one single fragrance that can be worn as a perfume or used as room fragrance. Of course, it had to be named ‘Out of this World’, and it will take you all the way from Earth to the heart of the Milky Way; I like to think of it as the T.A.R.D.I.S. of the perfume world!

Who am I, and how did I come up with this?

Hello, I’m Marina, a forty something year old perfumer who, until ten years ago, was terrified of science, because it made me feel inadequate in a world full of what I thought of as ‘clever people’. In my thirties I had a revelation…my own curiosity was pushing me towards discovering the world around me, and slowly, without meaning to, I fell in love with science, and I discovered that it doesn't have to be difficult and boring. The main difference between many of those clever people and me was that they were encouraged to discover the wonders of science as children and young adults by their families and teachers, whilst I had been discouraged from doing so.

Sadly, this is a story many of us know, and one that is still common in today’s society. Things need to change, and AromAtom is here to encourage and support that change, by presenting science in a fun way for children and adults. You are never too old to fall in love with science!

As a perfumer, my own curiosity has always made me wonder about why things smell the way they do, and when something doesn't have an odour, I can't but imagine and create fantasy smells in my mind for these 'odourless' things. It is my fascination with both space science and fragrance that has led me to create AromAtom, an interactive and innovative experience, that uses olfactory journeys to engage with STEM subjects that are often perceived as difficult and challenging.

Creating blends in the perfume lab

The Impact                                    

AromAtom is for everyone. At its most basic level, its primary aim is to demystify science by presenting it as a fun and accessible experience that anybody can participate in, regardless of age, education or background. This will be achieved in two different ways:

1.    Introducing the AromAtom experience through exhibitions aimed at people of all ages. These will be held at a number of art venues and science fairs, where we hope to reach people of all ages.
2.    Taking the AromAtom experience to schools, science clubs and educational events, with the specific aims of igniting the imagination of children and young adults, and encouraging them develop an interest in science.

I believe that it is imperative to make science more fun, exciting and accessible for all.  Combining olfactory art with science creates a platform to explore STEM subjects in a fun and innovative way, by introducing them through an array of weird and wonderful smells.

Where will the money go?

Participants will be exploring several bodies found in the Solar System, as well as other parts of the galaxy and the universe. For each area explored we need the following:

  • At least four banners and posters displaying relevant images and facts;
  • Booklets and fact-sheets explaining how each place would smell and why, including fun astronomy, chemistry and geology information, to complete the experience while participants are smelling;
  • Fragrance raw materials to create several scents;
  • Bottles and vials to store the blends;
  • Smelling domes and smelling strips;
  • Laboratory testing of artistic fragrances to ensure they are safe for use.

We also need to cover costs for website hosting and maintenance, promotional materials and venue hire.

What do you get in exchange for your support?

There are a number of perks for supporters, including AromAtom merchandise, private exhibitions, and the 'Out of this World’ fragrance created by Marina Barcenilla Parfums in collaboration with 4160 Tuesdays, two independent perfumeries owned by two of geekiest perfumers in the UK!

Risks & Challenges

The AromAtom exhibition pilot will be hosted in London on November 16, and I expect there will be a few lessons to be learnt from it. I am confident that this will be a positive learning experience for everyone, but I will be actively seeking out new ideas and feedback to ensure future AromAtom exhibitions are relevant and inspiring.

I have also designed a pilot school experience and I am currently in contact with a couple of local schools interested in hosting the AromAtom experience as part of their science engagement program. Special importance will be given to feedback from parents and teachers.

Other Ways You Can Help

I realise that not everybody who is interested in supporting AromAtom can contribute, but this doesn’t mean that you can’t help! You can help us spread the word about this project by talking to the people around you and by sharing it on social networks. If you follow blogs, celebrities or radio/TV/press journalists who are interested in science, space, education or fragrance, please ask them to take a look at this page and to talk about the project.  This would be of enormous help!

Special mentions

Huge thanks go to Apiary Studios in London, who have offered to host the launch of the pilot exhibition on 16th November free of charge. Also, to Sarah and Harry of 4160 Tuesdays for helping out with the creation of several fragrance elements, and to Sarah and Nick for coming up with the name AromAtom, and the #spacesmellslike hashtag.

www.mbparfums.com

www.apiarystudios.org

www.4160tuesdays.com

www.pochpac.co.uk

www.stortchemicals.co.uk

www.nostara.com

www.perfumeartschool-uk.com
